Review Title: Very Good Security Camera, Please Read If Discouraged by Other Avg. Reviews
Review Text: I read many of the reviews and almost did not purchase the camera because of them. However, after making the decision to buy two and using them for the past 3 weeks, I have been very pleased. Prior to my purchase I owned a RING doorbell, and since I have purchased a RING floodlight cam. All of my cameras work extremely well.I wanted to address the comments some people are making about these cameras as I think they are a little inaccurate. The battery life is not poor. I have two cameras on the back of my house and they ran on the original battery for 3 weeks. To ease concerns about poor battery life, I have had my cameras set on the standard motion detection setting and 3 weeks is pretty good. Additionally, each camera holds two batteries so ideally you can get up to 6 weeks without changing the batteries at all. We have a lot of deers, rabbits, etc in addition to our dog so our motions probably go off more than the average household.As far as video quality, these work well at night and in the day. I watch my kids in our backyard when they walk the dog at night, and I'm able to see them fine. If you want high def like watching a movie then sure, the video quality is not up to that standard. However, if you want to see if anyone is trying to break into your house or simply monitor your yard when you're home or not at home, it is perfectly fine.In terms of motion sensitivity, there are two settings that allow you to control the sensitivity. I think some of the reviews were a little misleading and perhaps they did not familiarize themselves with the app. There is a setting that basically lets you set the motion distance from the camera that you will pick up alerts. There is also an additional setting that let's you change the sensitivty with three settings that are equivalent to a high, standard, and low. I find these work just as well as my Ring floodlight.At the end of the day if you want all of your cameras to be in the same product family, or you just want to install some motion lights with the hassle of having to get a hard power line to them, I think these are great. Installation only took me about 15-20 minutes per camera, and part of that was adjusting the field of view of the cameras to my liking.I would highly recommend these cameras.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2018

Review Title: Super Easy to Install, no wires necessary!
Review Text: I have a Ring pro on my front door and loved it so much that I wanted something for the back patio since I have contracts (lawn, pool, trees, etc) in my backyard. My challenge however is that all the walls on the patio are either stucco or rock, which makes it near impossible to run a hidden power line.  So I opted for this option and so far it works great. The lights are pretty bright and the motion detection works as expected.As for the battery life, it has been in for a couple weeks and it has lost about 10% battery. So I’m guessing it will last about 3 months before it needs a charge. I just ordered a second battery which should double that battery life.The connection is very quick, it seems to connect much faster than my front door, but in fairness it is closer to the wireless router.As for installation, I installed it using the provided screws into the frame of my patio door. It actually works perfect there because you can’t really see it and allows me to perfectly position it for motion detection.My only complaint is the motion zone setup. Unlike the ring pro where I can “draw” motion zones (which significantly helps reduce motion alerts), it only allows you to specify a distance. It really isn’t very intuitive, so I just leave it at mid-range and it seems to work just fine for now.Beware, in order to have video playback, you do have to subscribe to the ring premium service. And you have to have a subscription per device! I have it for my front door, not sure I’m gonna pay for the back door. That was kind of a bummer to find out I’d have to pay more. It should be a household subscription.Overall, I’m very happy with the device and would recommend it to anyone looking for an easy to install solution without wires.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2018

Review Title: Inaccurate at times, but still workable
Review Text: I've previously owned Arlo security cameras, and I have both Ring security cameras and Arlo cameras at my house. My Ring cams don't connect to my WiFi router consistently, so I was advised to buy a ring WiFi extender. The Arlo base device seems to be more consistent with WiFi connections. On the Ring mobile app, it doesn't provide thumbnail image previews like Arlo, and the app crashes a lot because it can't connect to my cloud account. Live view on the Ring app does not always work and sometimes all I get is a black screen on the mobile app. As a result, the ring cam itself does not always do what you want it to do. It does have some good features, like the LED lights, motion snooze modes, motion proximity settings, and double battery packs, but I'm sticking primarily with Arlo until Ring upgrades their mobile app.

Review Title: I looked at several cameras and I liked the concept of the Ring cameras and what they ...
Review Text: I had high hopes and expectations for Ring products but so far I've been extremely let down.  I looked at several cameras and I liked the concept of the Ring cameras and what they had to offer for my needs.  So I just threw caution to the wind and invested in several to build a multi-camera system (3 Spotlight Cams ( w/2 batteries and Solar Panel ea) plus a Floodlight Cam.  In hindsight that alone was a mistake because of not knowing how they were going to work for sure.  Didn't get them up right away and that prevented me from being able to return them.  Had to change to a new cell carrier and internet service just to have enough speeds for the cameras to work.  And I still had to invest in 2 Ring Chime Pros to get a decent signal to them.  SO I have invested a fair amount in Ring and am STUCK with Ring for now (1,100 plus dollars__BIG MISTAKE).  I wanted one more Ring camera but that's indefinitely put on hold...( looking at Nest cameras right now...maybe they can do better)  Maybe it's their turn now...Ring has had theirs and is failing at this point.  Competition leads to better products anyway right.The lag and slow response times, inconsistent less than stellar video quality, flat out failures and too many more to list so I'll stop there. It's falling flat before it's really out of the gate.  At least for me it is.  Now whether some of these issues are related to the app...who knows.  And regarding tweaking things,  that's fine IF it's a one time thing but if these systems are so sensitive to things or certain hardware etc then this becomes like a house of cards...one thing slips out of place and the whole thing comes down.  I don't have time to be part of the R&D team.  If that's the case I'd be better off with ADT or Xfinity security monitoring.My speeds are solid, my camera/signal health is good. My cell service is a nationwide top end service so at this point my commitment to Ring is fading fast and that window is closing.  With Jeff Bezos and Amazon behind Ring I really expected better than this.  I'm a Amazon Prime member and Amazon has never let me down...so this is really frustrating and disappointingAt this point these cameras are useless to me as a security/monitoring device.  A novelty at best...and that is when they work consistently.I really would like for this to work and I'm sure somewhere in there is a good product line but so far for me I'm not impressed and couldn't recommend Ring Products for what they are marketed to do

Review Text: UPDATE From previous review below:  I'm now downgrading my review from 2 stars to 1.  Why?  Well, I was reached out to from Ring about my problems and they were initially very helpful.  Even replaced my "Battery operated" camera for a "Wired one" saying it would give me better reliability.  Well after only 3 weeks, the microphone stoped working so I couldn't communicate with visitors at my door - only see them.  So I once again reached out to Ring, only this time they kept going round and round with me for a month asking silly questions about my wifi, wifi extender, what's my pnone, have you tried on you computer, on and on and on.  They simply wouldn't accept that their camera's microphone was busted on this 3 week old device.  So I just gave up and told them never mind.  It was infuriating.  So, for my initial $199 purchace, Ive simply got a camera that does nothing else.  Big deal!  It's 2019.  Terrible service!Ok, I've waited almost two months before writing a review on this camera.  I wanted SOOOO Much to like it, but I'm afraid I can't.  I've adjusted locations several times, played with ALL the range, sensitivity and quadrant options. Someone could easily steal a package from my front door and be off before I even get an alert.  So sorry Amazon, you bought a company that could be a lot better in my opinion.

   I was honestly looking forward to getting this camera for my home, but don't make the same mistake I did. I have had issues with this camera from the moment it went up, and the support from Ring only made things more frustrating. From the start...the package is great - it comes with everything you need...even the drill bit! The battery took a few hours to charge, but never indicated it was done charging - even though it was 100% when I put it in the camera. After 24 hours, the battery was reduced by 1%, so don't expect it to last 6 months or as long as Ring suggests it will. The battery is not secured and can be easily stolen (Ring will only cover it up to a year). I was a little shocked it was so easy to get to.Getting the camera setup with the app was fairly simple and easy to do. Connecting to the camera after that was a gamble. Sometimes I could connect, sometimes I couldn't. Sometimes the wi-fi signal was OK, sometimes it was poor. And by the way, the device was located about 20 feet from the wireless router. Pretty much every other device has a perfect signal where the camera is located, including an old IP camera I had there for 5+ years.Night one - 47 degrees outside, and condensation forms over the camera lens completely (see the image and video). This was never an issue with the old camera (not a Ring product), so I contact Ring Support to see what's up. After a 45 minute wait, Ring support suggested I wipe the lens. Clearly, this is not something I would have thought of myself?!? After taking a few deep breaths and explaining I did that, the next suggestion was to move the camera. The weather doesn't change a few feet away, so this was the most asinine of suggestions I received. The next solution was to wait for warmer weather. I am not kidding. Ring support suggested I wait for warmer weather. Finally, we looped back to relocating the camera. At that point, I just had to shake my head and laugh.I am returning this camera to Amazon and hope it gets destroyed. Do yourself a favor - DO NOT BUY THIS CAMREA. You'll regret it eventually.Update...One day after this review was posted, Ring contacted me (two different people) and wanted the opportunity to speak with me more. I was pretty much done with Ring, as you can gather from this review, but I agreed anyhow. A few hours later, I was on the phone with someone at the Ring offices. My experience this time was completely different. They didn't offer excuses or make absurd recommendations. To make a long story short, I gave them a second chance with a different camera. Actually, I was so hopeful after this, I now have two Ring devices (Doorbell Pro and Floodlight). Don't get me wrong, the battery camera is indeed horrible and I would never recommend it. I'll be leaving reviews on the other two devices, but they are much better in every way.

Review Title: USELESS: Recently updated App, makes motion sensor & cameras useless
Review Text: We have been happy with our 3 Ring cameras for a little over a year. We loved the custom ability provided with the motion sensors. In Sept 2019 they updated their app and took away ALL motion customization.It might not effect a home that is near a street, but for our home it no longer detects when anyone comes up to the house until AFTER they reach the door. So, they ring our normal doorbell BEFORE the Ring lets us know they are on our property.We loved that we were alerted when people pulled up to the home. With two adopted special needs children it gave us plenty of time to wrap up what we are doing to get to the door before deliveries were missed, or people are standing around. We also had plenty of time to answer the notice and speak to the person.Not anymore! :( Worse thing is they made the change. Shortened the distance the Ring detects, all without notifying us.How did we find out? Our neighbor was robbed and the guy walked right in front of the Ring and it DIDN’T pick him up at all. He was caught from a distance on other cameras standing only a few feet from the Ring and it NEVER detected him. We have everything set to high alert, super sensitive. The only thing that changed was their motion sensor customization.They made the change to save storage and money. So, their company could bring in higher profits at the customers expense.Our kids and family is less safe, all because someone somewhere decided we no longer needed motion sensor customization. Even though they still advertise it here as a product feature.Looking for an alternative. These cameras are now useless.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2019

Review Title: You're better off with the wired cam
Review Text: I have 3 Ring wired spotlight cams and wanted to put another camera in a spot that running a wire would be less convenient so I figured I would just go with the battery cam with the solar panel.  The solar panel works great, it keeps the battery at 100% even with only a few hours of full direct sunlight.  The first camera I received didn't work and after a few hours with the Ring CS, they decided it needed to be replaced. No big deal, things like this happen and they are easy to deal with for the replacement.  The second camera works  but not as good as the wired ones do.  First the motion settings are no where as detailed as the wired cam has.  The wired cam I can draw out the zone I want the camera to activate and that's perfect.  The battery spotlight cam doesn't do this.  The only motion setting available is the range so because of that I get too many alerts that I don't need to be getting.  The picture quality on this battery cam is also not as good as the wired cam either. With the wired camera you can turn it off for the times that you expect a lot of traffic in that area. Then you don't have to go back and delete all those captures of the kids playing or you washing your car.  The battery cam has no way to turn it off so I have to go back and delete, delete, delete.  At some point I'm going to have to replace this camera with the wired camera.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2018

Review Title: Best Security Cam Functionality at This Price Point
Review Text: First, full disclosure. I have no involvement with any product and receive no compensation for my views. I'm basically a tech-junkie and love home automation products and services.I did a lot of research on security camera functions and features before buying and installing a RING solution. I looked extensively at Ring, Nest, Arlo, D-Link, Blink and TP-Link with an eye towards 1) creating a multi-tiered security solution and 2) giving me the ability to watch over both my home/family and both of my elderly in-laws homes. The functions and features I evaluated included, (not an exhaustive list) doorbell function, two way communication via the camera, alarm capability, manual and scheduled lighting control,  motion-detecting lighting control, security camera resolution (1080p) , night vision, accuracy of and variability in motion-sensing zones, wireless capability and range, live view from cameras, stored and recorded video from cameras, both battery operated AND hard wired power source, battery life, ease of setup and maintenance, compatibility with ALEXA, and solar charging capability for battery operated systems.Everyone is going to have their own opinion on each of these brands and the importance of the functions evaluated, but for me, Ring won out in most (almost all) categories.  Arlo would have been my second choice. It missed the mark in a just a few areas, whereas the Ring products seemed to provide just about everything I wanted across the product line and provided some features and functions that just blew me away.Even 6 months after installing 2 Doorbell Pros (wired), 3 Indoor cameras, 3 Floodlight Cams (wired), and 3 Spotlight Cams (2-battery/solar charged) on three different properties, and linking them into my Ring Account and  Alexa environment, the system still works almost flawlessly and keeps both me and my wife fully informed about what's going on around our house, at her parent's home and at their vacation home. When someone comes to the door at the in-law's place, we both get an 'alarm' on our phones and via Alexa indicating that someone has rung the doorbell at their house, which then allows us to open the Ring app and 'answer the door' for them because they can't get down the stairs to the door as quickly as they used to. (We gave them an Echo Show to answer the door with, but unfortunately, remembering the phrase, "Alexa, show me the Front Door camera" seems to be beyond capability on some days.  It works great when they can remember it though...)The Ring Spotlight and Floodlight cams will turn on the lights at night when someone comes into the motion-sensing 'view' of the cameras. If I'm wondering who (or what) it might be, the security light is sufficient to light the area in color at 1080p resolution (at night!).  If I want to look at a secured area in a low-light situation, the night-vision cameras give a good enough resolution to let me see my cars, the bushes, wild animals (we live in a wooded area), our cats, and just about everything else.Speaking of the cats...  That is the ONLY complaint I have about any of the Ring products.  The motion-sensing controls are supposed to be adjustable so that the camera will be able to distinguish between small animals and humans at anywhere from 3 to 30 ft. away, but despite trying several settings, focal lengths and angles, none of the cameras seem to be able to tell the difference between a moving 3lb  cat and a 150lb person, let alone a flag or a bush moving in a light breeze.  I'm sure the technology exists to do this accurately...  whether we would be willing to pay the added price might be the real issue.  Until they get that worked out, I just turn off the 'motion alerts' for cameras where I know I'm going to get constant alerts and leave the 'light alerts' on, so if it is a person, they know they've been seen.  The cats, dogs and bears... they couldn't care less.  Turning on a light due to movement burns more battery, but the solar panels always seem to bring the power back quickly to 100% even on cloudy days, so it hasn't been much of an issue.My wife and I also like that all video (with audio) is recorded and stored in the Cloud (added cost feature, but well worth it and not that expensive in my view). She finds it comforting to know that her parents have gotten back home from their daily outing and made it safely back in the house in real time, but she can also check on the history of who has come and gone at any time, day or night.  Did their grocery delivery come today as scheduled?  Ring can tell her.If you have a second home in another state, as long as you leave the electricity on and internet access available,  you can monitor the place inside and out from wherever you are, turn on and off security lighting, talk to 'visitors', record any activity, and set off an alarm if necessary. It's the poor man's version of 24/7 monitored security.If you have simpler needs or are just starting out with home automation/home security I still believe Ring is a great choice for a starter, and it's easily expandable. Just taking security camera solutions into consideration, Ring does everything that the others do and provides some features that others simply don't, like the built-in motion-enabled security spotlight or floodlight, or the free replacement guarantee if one of your cameras gets stolen.  Expanding the scope into other capabilities, Arlo didn't get to 1080p until Arlo Pro 2, only recently came out with a security doorbell, and their cameras still don't have security lights.  And Arlo, in many cases, is just more expensive than Ring.The only 2 things Arlo Pro 2 can do that Ring cannot are 1) record 24/7; and that will only happen with a wired camera, not a battery operated version, and 2) store video to a USB storage target. But since I am not using these security cameras in a traditional security setup, I don't care. (In a traditional security setup, multiple cameras do 24/7 recording to a computer system that stores multi-track video for a set period of time.  If that is what you need, you either have to go with Arlo or a dedicated security cam setup.Bottom line: Both Ring and Arlo are capable solutions. As an overall security package, nothing else even came close.  For me, Ring edges out Arlo as an 'entire package' because I wanted something that had a doorbell option and security lighting included. (Arlo's doorbell is a recent offering, but their cameras still lack lighting) The 'free replacement if stolen' guarantee and the Ring Community put them over the top in my estimate. (The Ring Community allows Ring owners in a common geographic area to share captured video to ask questions about events, warn people about various situations or just show funny stuff caught on camera.  No owner or their exact location is identified, although a map of the general area is provided to orient yourself to the events being reported.Ring is fully functional, continually growing and expanding its product line in really useful ways, it's competitive in cost, and easily expandable.  And, Ring is owned by Amazon, which really can't hurt its future competitiveness.  For me, Ring was a natural choice.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2019

Review Text: How is this not a known thing? 30 seconds of recording followed by a lengthy period of time before the next recording! The only way to record longer is to be in live view! So it will record someone coming up your driveway or on your porch,but not what happens if they stay there. I set it up in my driveway to keep an eye on my cars....well I was at the end of my driveway taking out the trash,which it recorded for 30 seconds, to far away to see anything other than the shape of a person...then walked up my driveway, got in my car,started it and drove away....not a single part of that was recorded!  Today I pulled in my driveway, it started recording, stayed in my car for 15 seconds, it stopped recording, I legit walked up to it,picked it up and carried it around my deck for 3 minutes before it sent me another notification about motion,zero video of me getting out of the car or picking the camera up and walking around with it.....the only possible way to make the video record for more than 30 seconds is to open the live feed in the app within the 30 seconds of the initial motion detection! So if it's 4am,someone walks up your driveway and you sleep through the notification, you have 30 seconds of video! If your in a pool on vacation obviously without your phone,you have 30 seconds of video! If someone is breaking into your home and you go get something to protect yourself instead of opening the app and going to live feed you have 30 seconds of video...then nothing, no video,no audio,no more alerts for a few minutes! If you pull in your driveway, walk in your home,check your mail,take out your trash the cameras have already recorded at least 10 seconds,you get the notifications but know that it is you activating them.......but,someone is 20 seconds behind you.....there is no video,no audio, no alerts.....nothing! This is not a security camera! It gives a false sense of security just because it has live view and alerts!

Review Title: Very poor motion detection and lacks options of other brands/models
Review Text: I was very disappointed in this product.  I bought it as I loved that it was wireless and had a companion solar panel (which worked great) to avoid having to hassle with taking batteries out to recharge.Unfortunately the camera just didn't work well for several reasons.1. Review Title: Only records for 30 seconds! Then 50 seconds of no recording
Review Text: I feel compelled to write a review based on my experience with the ring spotlight camera.  I bought this camera because it is battery powered and recorded at 1080p.  I owned the ring doorbell for almost a year before buying two of these spotlight cameras and really liked how the ring doorbell functioned.  There are three things that caused me to rate the ring spotlight camera two stars:1) the battery life is not what is advertised.  My two batteries in each camera last at best three weeks.  I live in a cul de sac so there isn't hardly any foot traffic or cars driving by but the batteries drain fast.  There is an option to not record every motion but I find that defeats the purpose of having a surveillance camera.2) the camera doesn't record some movements, I'm not talking about a small animal, I mean HUGE objects like when the trash truck pulls up to empty the trash cans.  I find this to be completely unacceptable.  It happens all the time.3) the ring spotlight camera only records for 30 seconds!  I called ring support because I was missing some critical video recording segments.  Motion would activate the camera and it would record for 30 seconds, then stop recording.  If the motion continued it wouldn't record again until 50 seconds had passed!!!!!  Then if there is motion it will record again for 30 seconds then no recording again for 50 seconds!  Imagine if someone is breaking into your car/house?!?!!!  That is crazy that the ring spotlight camera is like this.  The ring representative I spoke with said there was no way to adjust the record times on this camera.  I invested a lot of money into ring cameras but I am going to look into another camera that is continuous recording.  No point in having a camera that doesn't capture data, especially when motion is happening.  I recommend another camera if you are serious about security.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2019

Review Title: Spotlight Cam a Disapointing Ring Product - Update 20 July 2019
Review Text: Purchased the Ring Doorbell (wired) and the Spotlight Cam (outfitted with two batteries) on February 26, 2019. I found, after installing and setup, the Cam is not the same technology as the Ring Doorbell. Spotlight Cam shared the same wireless connection to the same ATT router as the Ring Doorbell. Ring Doorbell responds flawlessly. Spotlight cam is the same wireless distance as the doorbell but has connected only intermittently from day one. Added ATT Mesh Network to increase signal strength to minimize drop out. I even added a Net-Gear Extender. Every device in my house benefitted from the additions with one exception- - -the Spotlight cam.  After being "on-line" for less than 60 days, but beyond the 30 day return, The Spotlight Cam finally Gave up the Ghost. It went into an off-line mode and has been in that state ever since. I have implemented ALL the recovery steps recommended by Ring but this product is dead as a doornail. The Doorbell? It's still working flawlessly. The Spotlight Cam? Makes a great paper-weight but I would not recommend the Spotlight Cam as a security cam. I am currently researching other products to replace it.This in an update on the above review: After a number of email conversations with the Ring Support Team, the decision was made by the team to replace my camera under warranty, Although it took some effort to get to that point, once the they made that decision the continuing support was fast and efficient. The replacement camera came immediately. The replacement camera connected to my network with no issues and is working with no operational issues. As a suggestion for those thinking about purchasing the battery version as I did, I would add the solar option in addition as I found that if you intend to use all the options the camera provides, the battery life is decreased. Also, the latch that holds the hinged battery cover is a little flimsy and does not want to snap closed easily. Although it does work, I feel the less you have to open and close it the better. The customer support follow-up was top notch. I gave the product 4 out of 5 stars because of the cover latch issue. If ring can improve that I  would give it the full 5 stars.

Review Title: Live video signal never appears while people are there.
Review Text: These Ring products really have potential. If they did what they claim they do, I’d be a happy camper. I have the Ring Pro doorbell, the Ring Battery Stick Cam for indoor use, and the Ring Battery Spotlight camera (which was an Amazon Treasure Truck deal). My main complaint is right there in my Subject line. These cameras are so slow to produce a live video on whatever device you’re using (I’m using an iPhone XS Max). Without going through all of the hooops and jumps that their tech support always does (and they always say, “Well golly gee whiz, I’m so surprised you’re having these issues. We rarely have anyone call with the type of issues you’re experiencing”. I hope they get paid well to say that, because it’s just not the truth. Go see for yourself and ask ANYONE who has Ring Video systems inside or outside their house. Ask them how long it takes after someone rings their doorbell until they have a live video of the front door. What you will hear is, “The people are gone by the time it turns on”, or you will hear, “It connects, but the picture is all pixelated and you can’t see OR hear what’s being said. I’ve had it with this system and I hope you read this before buying., Do your research and find out what a good system is (there are tons of them now). I can’t recommend one because I think they will delete my review for naming another product (that they sell on Amazon). The amazingly poor performance of these Ring products is pretty shocking, considering that I put a decent amount of money into this whole system so that I could have the “ring of protection”. Ring has tried to blame the issues on everything under the sun, but what they don’t know is that they are talking to a tech repair guy. I know what a real fix is and what a phony fix is. They always try to blame your WiFi, even though the unit’s self-test says your WiFi signal is “better than 80% of Ring users”. It’s not my WiFi, it’s not my wiring (because they run on rechargeable batteries), it’s just their products. They’re poor quality and just don’t work. Once in a blue moon when I CAN get a live signal, the video signal on my iPhone XS Max is absolutely amazing. Crystal clear, and you can zoom in and out using finger gestures. They better come out with a “fix” for these ultra-poor video products or their recent billion dollar business is going to be a name in the heap of other hi-tech companies that didn’t make it either. Best of luck to you! (If you already bought one, return it and get a different brand!! Seriously, it’s THAT bad. I had a friend bring over his WiFi cams and we connected wirelessly to my home WiFi network. Not a single problem. Instant video and sound, crystal clear audio in both directions, it was fantastic and it proves (again) that it’s not anything wrong I’m doing—-it’s their products. They don’t work right.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2019

Review Title: Large investment - does not work as promised.
Review Text: Complete disappointment! Doesn't catch motion of people - ever. Catches trees blowing though! Every 30 seconds it triggers the camera and then records the tree blowing for a minute. But real motion - if it's caught - might record for 10 - 20 seconds. If real lucky it will record 30 seconds of a moving object and then nothing will trigger again - even loading a car on a trailer!Batteries don't last even when trees aren't blowing. I purchased solar panel chargers, as well for power reliance.I have called Ring multiple times but it appears it's just a bad product because it never gets better. The support team tries but it becomes hours of wasted time.Resetting cameras is extremely painful as a button on camera has to be pushed. (Some cameras must be opened to push button) Climbing up and down ladders to push those reset buttons when be it's 100+ degrees is a terrible experience. Outdoors you can NOT see any light flashing to pair in many of the models. This model has a flashing light 'globe' on the bottom but the door with this one doesn't hinge tightly onto the camera base to close it!  It doesn't stay closed until you mess with it and then don't breathe hoping it will stay.Often the camera has to be taken down to reset in trying to make it work. The first thing Ring support wants to do is run a WiFi test - which 'hello' - I've done multiple times, I've reset the modem, router and camera. Then they say 'reset the camera' - which by be the time I call I've done at least 5 times as well.The ability to connect to WiFi is poor. Other brands in the same location connect and stay connected. They respond to motion. The Ring cameras don't trigger when someone walks to the car in full vision of the camera, gets in the car and drives off. View 1: car in driveway 2: next view car 'poofs' into disappearance! No motion of anything in between. I took the camera down and waived a towel in front of it and it never triggered to start recording video.I started out with a single battery. It didn't last so I bought another battery. Still the camera - connected to a solar panel - didn't last past 5 pm. Could not do 'live views' with constant low battery notice. I had turned off the spotlight feature but it made no difference. Why buy a spotlight camera if the spotlight feature had to constantly be turned off in hopes the camera might work and the batteries might last past dusk?The voice communication is horrible. No one can understand or even know you are trying to talk to them. If they respond in anyway, you can't understand what they say.Signal reported by camera in app is ~36 or occasionally up to 50 but that's rare. I've got a whole house mesh wireless system that I bought thinking my Netgear Nighthawk wasn't maintaining a strong enough signal even with the powerful booster extender and good signal at the camera locations. I ran all the cameras on a different channel than other IoT devices.I have a large investment that is not working and does nothing to provide security. I've been trying to work with Ring for 5 years giving them every chance, buying the newer cameras, resetting and resetting cameras.I also added fiber to improve the network. Nothing has worked to make the Ring cameras perform as promised.I have purchased several models of cameras. The first stickups were more reliable but 720 just doesn't cut it.  Sadly, I could never recommend Ring with the experience, expense of cameras, invested time and additional equipment expenses I have had.I could have and should have hired a good security company to install a camera system that worked for much less at this point. Frustrating!

Review Text: So I'm comparing this battery powered model to our wired model we also have installed. There are definitely trade offs you have to make if you go with the battery model over the wired model. The biggest difference is the night vision video quality. The battery model does not support true infrared assisted night vision, obviously since this would deplete the battery in only a few days. Also the motion detection system is not as sophisticated. On my wired model, I can set specific zones where I want alerts if motion is detected, or vice versa. For example, I do not want my flags on the front porch setting off our camera, so I can customize the motion settings to ignore the areas with the flags. The battery powered model simply has a range/sensitivity slider that determines it's range. On the plus side the battery in the battery powered model lasts almost a solid two weeks before it needs recharged. Also the easy of installation is nice. All in all if you have a way to install the wired camera, go that route as you will be happier with the camera features and video quality.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2019

Review Title: Live on a busy street? Do not buy!!!!
Review Text: I was about to return this product. The only reason I didn't. Was because I thought it would save on my electric bill, because I wouldn't have to leave my porch lights on allnight. And it does do a decent job and is atleast some protection.I was very frustrated, that it did not mention a Ring Protection Plan was REQUIRED! Without it the device(s) are useless. The info on the page made it seem like a plan was optional and not needed for operation. And twice now, a delivery person has dropped off a package at my door and the device did not catch them! Although, to be fair, it did catch the back of one of the delivery persons'.If you live on a busy street do not buy this! It will go off continuously! And no amount of motion sensor tuning will fix it. I mute the notifications (it still records events).The neighborhood feature is nice, but if you live in a major city. I suggest narrowing down this feature to within a few blocks of your home. I live in Baltimore. 5 miles had this thing giving me updates from across the harbor!Picture quality is also good day and night. But I tried to zoom in on a vehicle's tag during daytime, 10ft from my door and couldn't read it.I'm waiting to see if the talk option works. Delivery people move to fast for me to try it out. If it doesn't I am returning it.***UPDATE***After working with Alexis (CS). I am happy to say my spotlight cam is working a whole lot better! I still get a lot of motion alerts, but the false events have decreased greatly.  And my battery life has improved. It use to only last a week. A week has passed and I still have half the battery remaining!****UPDATE****After working very well for two days. My spotlight camera has been working like it did when I first bought it. The vast majority of motion events are false. There's no one walking past or any cars driving past the camera, but it still goes off. Even with the motion zones turned off. The camera is still giving me false motion events. I was thinking of getting a ring doorbell, but they have motion sensors in them to (all of them). And that will be right on the street as well. And if I can't turn off the motion sensor. I'm not going to even bother.

Review Title: and over all I'm happy. Camera/"live view" started working better about a day ...
Review Text: Bought this for the front door, with the solar panel, which keeps the single battery at 100% full time.  System works fairly well, and over all I'm happy. Camera/"live view" started working better about a day after I set it up, most likely due to firmware updates being applied. I had to fiddle a bit with motion sensitivity, but it's very useful to review comings and goings. The speaker isn't great, but it is handy in a pinch if you need to communicate with a delivery person or something. I'm considering a few AC-wired floodlight cams for the periphery. The hardwired are better as they record continuously, vs the battery powered which only start recording on motion. Didn't realize that when I bought it, but I don't have existing power to that location so no problem. It would be nice if Ring was doing more with PoE, as I imagine a few of these devices running on your WiFi will likely impact other device's connectivity.  When I get around to it I will create a separate WiFi network just for the cam(s). Ring is currently sending all data unencrypted, which is unfortunate if you don't trust your ISP or other middlemen. Hopefully with the recent Amazon acquisition, Ring gets influx of development and expertise, and the product will get even better.

Review Title: UPDATED Review - total waste of time and money
Review Text: Update - I updated my review from four to one stars.  Here's the reason why.  I have a RING Stickup and a RING Spotlight covering our pool and backyard.  Both are battery powered with attached solar units.  I've had some issue with the company that chemically treats our yard for weeds etc.  I knew they were coming a few days ago, so when I got home I pulled up the videos from our backyard (the aforementioned cameras).  One recorded him coming into the backyard but not leaving.  The other didn't record him or alert that someone had entered a motion zone (it was obvious from the one camera that he had in fact entered motion zones for both cameras).  I called RING Tech support and spoke with Mel.  Pleasant enough guy but not helpful. We started with the discovery my recorded length was 20sec when it should have been 30 which is the default.  I asked where I could change that and he gave me instructions, but the options he quoted were not available on any of my cameras.  He told me to delete the app and reinstall.  I did but still no joy.  He then said he could change it from their end.  Then we discussed zone settings and he said my RING Stickup camera had five zones with one turned off.  None of my cameras have five zones, they all have three.  I asked him for clarification and he repeated "from my end, I see five zones on the stick up camera and one is turned off).  Now, how does he see five zones and I see three?  We then tried to trouble shoot why the cameras were detecting motion but not recording.  NO CLUE, said he would have to escalate the problem (means throw in the white towel) but said he would send me an email outlining our discussion and assuring me he would continue to trouble shoot.  Got the email - basically said I should consider two step authentication (which I already had set up).  Replied that I was not satisfied and the one time I really needed the RING to work, it didn't.  He did reply and restated he was going to continue troubleshooting the issue.  Long story short - three of my battery RING cameras have proven unreliable.  The only one that seems to work worth a darn is the wired RING door bell.  Total waste of money.Purchased this along with a solar panel for our backyard.  A couple of positives are it is small and the install was easy.  Now the negatives in my opinion; the speaker is so small that it's impossible to use it to speak to anyone.  You can hear but it's squeaky.  I have two wifi extenders in our home in addition to our router and it's still hit or miss with how long it takes to connect when I get an alert.  It does offer peace of mind, but looking back I think there are a number of other products available that were cheaper and may perform better.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2020

Review Title: Poor night vision with Spotlight Cam Battery in comparison with other Ring cams
Review Text: UPDATE: I got contacted by Ring Customer Service and O was offered to exchange the Spotlight Battery Cam to Spotlight Wired one. Couldn't be happier with the exchange, wired works good. See below why night vision on Wired/Mount/Spotlight is better than on battery variant. And special thanks to Ring Support (to Jess, in particular), didn't expect that level of support!The quality of the night vision in my Spotlight Cam Battery is unacceptable. I have two cameras installed in the same spot - Spotlight Cam Battery and Ring Stick Up Cam Battery (later I tried the Spotlight Mount as well). The Stick Up camera (and Mount) shows bright b/w picture at night, while Spotlight Cam Battery shows very dim picture, like the IR lights are not even functioning for it (I can see red dots on its face, though).And yes, I tried to wipe the lens, I tried to reset the cam and to re-pair - no dice. HDR on / off doesn’t seem to make any difference either. There is no Color Night Vision option for the Spotlight Cam Battery (but it exists for the Mount variant, assuming it also exists for the Wired).On the attached pic you can see the screenshots of the Spotlight Battery (top) and Stick Up Battery (bottom). The difference is HUGE. Both of the cameras are installed at the same spot with the same light conditions. Both cameras are BATTERY powered, see my first post. Moreover, the Spotlight Cam Battery had 100% charge with the charger connected to it.UPD: Look at the pics, they show the difference in infrared light for Battery and Wired/Mount/Spotlight versions. The Battery variant has infrared lights on SIDES of the camera, while the rest of the family has them in FRONT. I believe this is the reason why the night vision is so poor for the battery version.I'd love to put 5 stars to Ring's Customer Service, but unfortunately this particular product has some design flaws and I can't give 5 stars to the PRODUCT. I am a huge Ring fan, I have multiple Ring product and I am mostly happy with all of them, well, other than the Spotlight Cam Battery thing. However, if you want wide field of view, good autonomy and don't care much about night vision - you can still choose this product.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021

Review Text: Overall this is a solid peace of security equipment that delivers piece of mind the moment when it’s activated. Solidly built and less of the energy hog i thought it would be. Besides, yelling at your significant others/kids when you get a notification is a lot of fun!I read the reviews prior to purchasing. Amazon could tell you that this sat in my cart for a couple of months as I wrestled with what cam to purchase. I was pleasantly surprised that all of my reservations became yarns spun by other security cam co’s.Battery life: ridiculously solid. I see tons of reviews that say get an extra battery or solar panel. I won’t be needing that. I don’t use the lights which may be why, but it’s at 60% after a month and a half of use (my ring goes off about 10-15 times per day). I’ve yet to charge it.Privacy: zones is a lifesaver as i have hanging plants in its view. It was picking up hummingbirds (didn’t know i had them!) so i adjusted the zone and ancillary alerts went poof. I still have it’s sensitivity set to high, but also only set to recognize people.Security: there were some recent break-ins in the neighborhood which was the impetus to purchase. A burglar went into our garage and poked around and while they are at large currently, they saw the cam and ran. We were able to easily give the video to the police. This thing delivers blockbuster quality in light and dark conditions, so we could easily see the culprit. They took nothing, but we took their image. Who’s laughing now? Me, as I watch the video over and over and bust a gut when they scram. Maybe look for the camera upfront (as it was RIGHT THERE!)What’s great: it’s portable! I could simply move this to a better location. Being a security freak, I will just buy a second.If I had to think of a downside, i’d be hard pressed to find one. It’s solid. You get alerts whenever there is action, and if I wanted to, I could be the eye in sky/big brother/intangible hand watching over my domain. For me the price matches the peace of mind I’ve gained as a return. Word.

Review Title: Wanted to rate it 5 stars but couldn't.
Review Text: I ordered two Spotlight Cam Battery units during the two days of Prime Day.  For the few minutes that I had them running, they worked as advertised but then came the problems.  The first camera's mount was defective and the camera itself took on condensation after a much-needed rain.  I called Ring and they replaced the mount and added 2 batteries to compensate me for my trouble.  Ring also replaced the camera, which I haven't received yet. Review Title: Very nice product with some minor glitches
Review Text: Overall, the Ring Camera works quite well. Its relatively simple to install and the camera works well. Here are my pros and cons:Pro:The camera works well (my guess the range is about 120 degrees.  The picture is sharp and the color is accurate. My iPhone picks up the camera well. The motion detection works well and there is a relatively small light that will come on if the camera detects movement at night. I mounted the camera on my garage which is about 25 feet from my house. (didn't work; see Con's).  I also bought the solar power device and it has recharged the battery to 100% each day (even a day with heavy clouds and rain).  Ring has a 24 hour tech support group and I found the staff to be pleasant and helpful. Ring's software is easy to follow and there is a help feature which is useful.Much like the Ring doorbell, the camera enables the user to listen and speak to anyone that is near the camera.Con'sRing suggests that buyers move the camera to different spots to determine if it is working well.  I received a good picture and the sound features worked well. However, I wasn't aware that should read the "signal strength" reading which is in the "Device Health" function for my camera. Signal strength must have a reading of 45 or lower.  My signal strength was 65 and the picture was slow and distorted from time to time.  I corrected the problem by putting an old range extender that I had in the garage and the signal strength quickly dropped to 39 (the lower the better).  The signal distortion vanished.. Ring offers a device to extend the wifi signal but the camera responds well to wifi extenders.The software settings are intended to allow the owner to stop motion detection. Unfortunately, the motion detection operates despite the software  and sends videos to my iPhone all the time. Also, I linked my Ring to my Amazon Echo and it reports motion detection aloud whenever the camera detects motion. Its easy to delete the unwanted videos but annoying to have to do so.  Also, it took about 5 calls to Ring to find out that the some of technicians know that this occurs while others don't know that. When you call Ring, the technicians can join the user to see what is going on in the camera software.  That is helpful but technicians see a different time period for stopping motion detection than the time period that the user has up on he/she's device. They know about this glitch but don't know how to fix it.The motion detector will can pick up bugs (like a moth or spider) if it is on the camera or flying by.  It will also report motion detection if there is a hard rain (and maybe, snow).The camera has a space for two batteries, but Ring only provides one. You can purchase a battery, I bought two since I have another Ring Camera on the way from Amazon. One of the technicians sent me a second battery because we were on the phone for a long time.  After an email about delivery acknowledgement six days ago, I am stilling waiting for the battery, but "one-offs" as the Ring staff call it, take 7-10 days for delivery.  I was told that direct purchases from Ring take 3-5 days for delivery.  Buying Ring batteries  from Amazon (which owns Ring) takes 2-3 days.If you purchase the Ring "Plus" warranty, you get an array of benefits.  One of the benefits is an extend warranty for the product as long as the warranty was purchased within the 30 day purchase date.  The Ring website says extended warranty continues as long as the Plus warranty exists. However, the website does not describe the elements of the product warranty.Ring offers a 10% discount on purchases if you own the Plus warranty.  Unfortunately, I was told by Ring that  the discount does not apply to purchases at Amazon; only purchases from Ring. This seems odd to me since Amazon owns Ring.Last thought, The cover on the Camera (which is on the bottom of the camera) doesn't appear to be water-resistant. Also, there are small holes that were used to screw the solar panel connection to the camera.  While solar panel no longer has plastic clamp that was previously provided, the holes for the screws are still there. There is a plastic slide that covers the holes but the slide is below the hole.  I think that water is likely to get in and I bought a cover from another company to remedy the cover and the hole problem.On balance, I like the product and believe that strengths of this product exceed the small glitches that I described. I have another camera on the way for use in the front of my house.

Review Text: Camera works great as advertised.  No issues.  But please note:  This is the Battery powered version of this camera setup and works as all battery powered cameras work, which is to say it starts recording when it senses motion and stops after a predetermined (programmable) time.  Of course there is a lag between all this starting and stopping so you will always miss the first couple of seconds of motion being recorded as the camera has to power on.  Which for the most part is not an issue, but if people quickly walk in and out of the recording area you may only get the back of their head as they are walking away.  If you mount this at your front door you will notice this a lot for Amazon or UPS deliveries as those delivery personal are very quick to drop off your package.  A lot of people complain about this, but this is really just the nature of a battery operated system.  While the Battery powered systems have their place, I would advise to only get one if you are mounting it in an area that has no nearby AC power.  Maybe a shed out back or something like that.  In order to always capture all motion, including the very quick in and out of a delivery person you need to have an AC powered Camera.  The big difference being the AC powered systems are continuously on and recoding everything, then when they detect motion they back up a few seconds before that motion was detected and save that whole scene.  So on the AC powered systems you will actually see the delivery person walking into your detection zone—nothing is missed.  Obviously the Battery powered systems can’t do this “continuous-record" feature as that would run the battery down in less than a day, so they have to run in an on-off mode.  Again I have two of these battery powered systems and for the right application they work fine as advertised, but just understand exactly what you are ordering and how it works.  My advice:  If you plan to mount anywhere near AC power, then get the hard wired version and take your time to tie it into you electrical system.

Review Text: This new camera is okay.  The setup wasn't too bad. Review Text: Edit: camera stopped picking up any motion today so it’s not recording anything. Only live view works. We’ve had it less than a week.I've had the Nest Cam Outdoor for a few years now. Its a great camera but the need to plug into a power supply isn't feasible so I settled for having it set up indoor facing out a window. The downside is night vision must be turned off as the window reflects like a mirror with the night vision light or inside lights turned on. It was also unsightly propped up on the window ledge with the cord hanging down. Decided to try this Ring camera. For us, the only upside is its battery operated so it can be mounted anywhere. Given the investment, if we were to start all over, we'd look into for the Arlo system.Here's our two deal breakers:1. Motion Zones customization with the Ring is very limited. You can select three zones that fan out almost 180 degrees and set how far they fan out. This likely works fine if you have a traditional front or backyard. We are in a busy area and  our houses are very close to the street so the zone is picking up every single person and car that goes by.  The result is a ridiculous amount of useless notifications. With the Nest, you can draw multiple zones to pinpoint an exact area you want to receive notifications.2. The Ring only provides clips vs a continuous feed history. In theory, this should be sufficient but I've found Ring Event History clips aren't recording the entire event. Example: the mailman came through our gate and into our patio to leave a package but the Ring only recorded him after he was back outside of the gate and walking away. It missed him opening the gate, walking into the patio, dropping off the package, walking back to the gate and exiting. If this would have been someone stealing the package the footage would have been useless. This has never happened with Next but if it did, you could scroll through continuous footage for several days or longer (depending on your plan). Since both cameras also see all the way to our neighbors house across the street, the continuous Nest history footage allows you to go back and see everything...not just what's in your notification zone. If a car gets broken into on the street, we can go back and see it. Something happens at our neighbors house, we can go back and see it. A suspicious person is casing the neighborhood but didn't come onto our property, we can go back and see it.A few pros:1. Motion activated spotlight is a useful feature.2. User activated alarm.3. Easy set up with a decent app.We will keep the camera but will still use the Nest camera in the window when on vacation.

Review Text: I have one by my porch angled in such a way that my front door and driveway are covered by this cam. Ring is easy to deal with and user friendly. My only shortcoming to report is that at times the connection can drop leading to the cam needing a little bit longer to bring up a live feed or to start recording.Update: owning several of these ring security cams has provided my family with peace of mind. However, there are noticeable quirks that must be known before investing in these cams. Your WiFi must be strong and bandwidth has to be fast, especially with more than one camera. Placement of the cams will also hinder the signal strength. I had a few weeks where everything was recording in black, audio was fine but the picture was completely black. I have a repeater in my garage to help with the cams that are furthest away from my router. After calling Ring for some tech support all they could offer me in terms of help is to upgrade my internet speed or move the cams closer. Neither was an option as I already have the fastest internet speed that my cable company offers and moving my cam would not cover the area I want to watch. Really simple tech support that is always user error or “slow internet” it’s never the ring cam.The motion sensor on the cam is adequate at this price point. It is not highly sensitive nor completely numb. Having said that we have noticed that overcast can play tricks with the sensor. Rolling clouds on a sunny day will trip the sensors. The shade from the clouds and then sunlight once the clouds pass will set off all of your cams. We have 5 and all of them go off at the same time. Kind of annoying but now we know.Another quirk with the sensor is that small animals such as a cat or puppy will trigger a sensor one time and then on subsequent passings it will not. Same animal but will record when it feels like. I feel there is an overall lack of continuity with the sensor and what it chooses to record.I wish the cam would record longer than 30 seconds per event but I understand there is a limitation with this capacity due to conserving  battery power (ring tech told me this).The ring cam is good but not great. I wish ring tech support would actually help instead of blaming the user or saying “it’s your internet speed.” I’ve stopped emailing and calling ring tech support because all they do is blame those two things.I like having a visible camera to deter unwanted individuals. We’ve noticed that neighbors with other security systems with hidden cams have had some vandalism and thefts. Those systems also failed to record such events or do not record with clarity or provide a spotlight to scare people away.Price point could be a little cheaper but the annual membership/subscription fee is relatively low.I downgraded ring from 5 stars to 3 stars based on horrible tech support and some of the inconsistencies we have experienced.

When a family member approaches the house, they are through the front door and inside the house before I ever get an alert on my phone. Review Title: Not worth the money if you want continuous recording.
Review Text: I’m not gonna lie, the ring cameras are great for someone who doesn’t care for continuous recording. I’ve owned them since 2018 and I’ve had a lot of small house and car break ins around where I live and this camera is not what I wanted. The recording time of only 30 seconds is straight up garbage. Even with the snapshots every minute does nothing good. I unfortunately have to stick ring cause I got sucked into the ring ecosystem, I got two cameras, and a doorbell and a 100$ annual subscription fee which isn’t bad but the fact that they don’t include continuous recording is just awful. Nest cameras on the other hand have continuous recording so I’m looking to upgrading to nest once my subscription expires.To quickly sum up my rant.This camera will not help in capturing crimes. A smart criminal will see you have a ring camera, activate it and then back off for 30 seconds and continue to break in your house.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020

Review Title: You have to pay $200 and then a subscription
Review Text: Ok this is crazy. So all this time I thought that once you have a ring camera its all yours, you have your own personal camera for your home. Little did I know you still have to pay monthly subscription for it, if you don’t  you cant see any videos it captured before, you can only watch live footage! So lets say someone stole something or someone came to your front door. It wont let you see the video it captured so once you go live that person is gone! So lets say someone stole something you have no video evidence to prove that person stole something from your yard. This is ridiculous, not sure why its $200 but yet you have yo pay a subscription. It’s completely pointless and defeats the purpose. You are better off buying a cheaper camera that doesn't have a subscription.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021

Review Title: I really wanted to like it.
Review Text: I'll be glad to review this again if things change. I purchased this because I like the alarm features. I did some reviews and watched YouTube videos about them so pulled the trigger. There was mixed information on whether or not videos can be kept if you do not have a subscription. I thought once it is on your phone then you basically have it, but this is not the case. I guess the main point for this review is to say the camera kept freezing the picture and then I would have to rejoin live view. I did find that somehow even though I couldn't see it on my phone that it did still keep recording. I know someone will ask about my WIFI and I checked it and made sure it was strong and there was no interference. I also found the view when I did see it was "walleyed-goggle eye" whatever you want to call it. So I have my trial now and basically, it has been no good to me. I have Blink cameras and the main reason I wanted to go to this was because of the different alert settings/sounds that it offers whereas Blink does not. So yeah, the only reason I gave it 3 stars was because it seems well built although heavier than other cameras in the market and because of the mentioned alarm features.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2021

Review Text: So I live in the city first and foremost... In my opinion, these are not designed for city use because the motion detection picks up way too much to the point you don't even bother checking the alerts at times. I have it on people only mode but it still picks up when a car goes by and things like that. Pretty annoying and it drains the battery. I don't really think there's a way around that which is okay. My biggest issue with the ring camera is that it doesn't constantly record like I had hoped. It records up to 60 seconds of motion and to me that's pointless. For example, Someone walks by and stands around by your car. Camera stops recording because where it has that timer... So if I go outside and my car is destroyed I will not have much proof if my $200 security camera didn't record the entire thing. I also pay for the storage space, What's the sense? This camera really does nothing for my needs. The night vision is "Meh" to say the least. You can barely see license plates, People don't show up that well. I guess if it's close to where the motion will be happening it would be very good such as right beside the front door but I have mine above the front door angeling towards the street (I only bought this to keep an eye on the family's cars)... You really can't see much at night in my opinion especially for a $200 camera. Now since I talked about the motion constantly going off (I understand this is because I'm in the city) just keep in mind this DRAINS the battery. My battery was fully charged when I installed it, I've had it about a week and it's already pretty much dead. That's annoying. I expected much more from this camera. I've also noticed when you set the alarm off (I did this for fun with a family member) you cannot hear the alarm going off on the ring app, And when the alarm is going off you can no longer hear anything.... I'm not crazy about that. The spotlight is very bright but to me it doesn't do much to really affect the camera quality. In my opinion, I wouldn't recommend this camera to anyone in the city, I'm sure if you live in a house somewhere it serves the purpose but if you're someone from the city considering this camera? I wouldn't do it unless you have money for either the solar battery charger (Which to me defeats the purpose of having a descret camera) or extra batteries. If I had it my way I'd return this and buy the security system I originally had my eyes on, I only went with ring because it's so popular. Not a fan. Wouldn't buy another one.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021

Review Title: Cameras do not show all movements. Skip
Review Text: Installation and setup is easy but cameras do not record all movements. They skip, not recording all activity so your unable to see every thing. Review Text: Bought this in July 2019, and it’s already dead. Jumped through all kinds of hoops between online help and phone support before Ring finally conceded it was dead, and that the company would not replace or provide any compensation or discount as it was 2 years old. This is a company that only stands behind its product until the sale is made.Even when it worked, there was a significant lag between receiving an alert and pulling up live view. Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2021

Review Title: Not a great camera, worse company, DO NOT GET FOR COLD CLIMATE
Review Text: I have a couple of issues with this company and camera.1) do not get this if you line in a cold climate area. If the temperature does below 10 degrees F, the battery is too cold to function. I would have hoped that this wouldn't be an issue on an outdoor camera.2) motion sensing is sometimes way too sensitive, and sometimes not sensitive enough. Today, it's gone off 15+ times in three hours for absolutely no reason. A few days ago, it didn't even start recording until a truck was fully parked in our driveway....3) we get more recordings of the neighborhood cats than the people who walk by our front yard. I get that it's a lot to ask for a camera to not pick up small animals, but it's still an issue.4) the cost.... The camera is already kind of expensive, but in addition you have to pay for a monthly subscription of $10/month to have any videos recorded. If you don't pay, there's no way to locally save the videos. You only get access to live feed. If you want to have another camera, the cost goes up to $25/mo which is pretty overpriced when you've already given them up words of $300 just for the cameras.5) I take issue with the fact that even though I pay a monthly fee to have access to the videos recorded from the camera, if I "answer" the video, it is not recorded. So if I want to look to see if the video being recorded is in fact someone hopping my fence (other than the neighbor's cat), and I happen to see a person... Well, I've just erased the evidence that I'd like to provide to the police.6) I don't feel secure in this camera being set up to my wifi. What are the chances that a company that is so careless with so many other things is going to have good security that protects my network? I've set it up on a separate secure network, and I would recommend others do the same. And I would NEVER ever consider getting their indoor cameras....I'm really not happy with this buy, but at this point I'm out the money for the camera, the solar panel, and the monthly fees I've already paid into it. If I decide to get rid of the whole setup, I'm not getting that back. Waste is money. I'm very disappointed.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021

Review Title: Buy the Wired version if possible!
Review Text: I bought this camera in July of 2018.  For the most part, it does its job but the wired version seems more fully featured, has a better picture and avoids issues faced by the battery one.  I was hoping to wait for their next update of the spotlight camera before picking up a wired one but more problems with battery one prompted me but a wired one on the Black Friday discount.First, Ring in general.  I received a Pro doorbell as a gift.  I had considered some cameras because I am away a fair amount and I also liked the idea of their alarm system which was still fairly new.  I had ADT and was fed up with their antiquated equipment, expensive monthly service (about $50/mo) and the fact they charged for every service call.  The Ring system offered more complete coverage, more up to date equipment and had a low monthly fee for monitoring and online recording.After installing the doorbell and finding it useful, I decided I wanted a front camera that covered the driveway and a back camera that covered my rear doors.  The Spotlights were on sale but you could only get the discount for one of each so I picked up on wired and one battery.  I mounted the wired one in back because there was a handy outlet.  The battery one was mounted out front.The rear, wired one has always been very responsive and provides a great picture.  It is about twice the distance from my wifi access than the front camera.  The only issue I have found is that it is still very sensitive even with the settings set as low as possible.  It doesn't seem to know the difference between a human and a small cat or squirrel.The front, battery one has always had some issues.  It constantly has connection issues even when I purchased a chime pro.  The chime pro is maybe 6 feet from it with a window between them.  I always get a poor connectivity message in the app.  Next, they updated the app several months or maybe a year ago to give you a pop up when you linked to the device that asks if you are unhappy about the battery performance.  I'm not and have to batteries in it so I don't have this issue but there is no way to make it stop with the pop up.  This is the camera I use to see who is out front.  The pop up delays the response and I find that if someone is walking up they are already past the camera by the time I selected view and then closed the pop up about battery issues.  Now, it has decided the battery door is open and will indicate there are no batteries.  This is not the case.  The case was closed, it has two fresh batteries, it managed to take a picture of me trying to find the problem and seems to work fine from the website just not from the app.I will not buy another battery operated camera from them.  I would also like to see their devices work with 5GHz and the latest wifi standard.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2020

Review Title: Update: Ring redeems themselves after losing the most critical videos needed and paid for
Review Text: Update: via Ring app chat on Saturday I was able to get ahold of a Ring technical support representative. Christine did a great job of explaining why my Ring Extender wasn't working with my Ring Spotlight Camera. The Ring Extender only works with the alarm system components like the motion detectors, door and window sensors, etc. In order to get a camera extended you need to buy the Ring Chime which will extend the wifi to a remote camera. Now it makes sense to me, but I needed to buy another component. Since she understood the confusion and my frustration she ended up offering to send me a Chime free of charge! This poor wifi signal is what caused all of my video and connectivity problems, and the extender vs chime only working with alarm system vs camera systems explains why I still couldn't get a good connection even with the extender.First Ring Spotlight Camera worked great. 2nd camera wouldn't activate the spotlight at any time, no matter how many settings were activated. Camera originally working well was moved into the driveway from the front door but has a ton of problems recording video or uploading them to "the cloud". Two dozen recordings today that were not recorded, yet those are the ones I need to locate $200 worth of stolen equipment right from under the camera. Even though I have a range extender 8ft from the camera and about 10ft from the router!? It worked just fine after installing it but when I needed it the most it became useless.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2020

Review Text: I am writing from personal experience with product. I installed doorbell, rear exterior camera with spotlight, indoor chime, bridge unit and other exterior spotlights in order to protect my exterior.The problem is that unless you PAY A MONTHLY FEE IN PERPETUITY, you cannot see the recorded videos of people coming to your house. They don't tell you that up front.So if you don't pay the extorted monthly charge, the system is useless as far as I'm concerned.Yes, you can remotely view a live cams of house on your phone at any time but who has time to constantly monitor their premises like a security firm.And, if some trips your doorbell or other security cams, you will get an alert on you phone,BUT by the time you go to the live cam view to see who's there and interact with them like they show on TV,they are long gone.  I have actually been in my house, gotten an alert on my phone and gone to the front door and found that a package was delivered but the guy was long gone. Wheres the advantage of that, Useless.If you don't mind paying a monthly charge for the recorded videos then go for it. I guess its nice to see when someone does something nice for you like they show in their TV ads, but is that why you are buying this for?This is a terrible product for home security unless you just feel like seeing some after the fact videos,and paying a monthly bill for that privilege.One more thing, after I called, told them about my concerns and requested a full refund, within a half hour they remotely rang my doorbell about 10 times in a row and then about an hour after that, they rang it another 5-6 times. Crazy i know but absolutely true.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2020

Review Title: Great Camera - Till Your Wifi Information Needs to be Changed!
Review Text: I installed this camera about 6 months ago. It works OK. Motion detection is fine night vision is very grainy. However, there is one show stopper. If you change your WiFi system, you will need to reset the ring camera to setup your new WiFi settings ... but guess what... In order to reset the camera you have to press a button on the Camera. Most people mount these cameras up high, and will need a ladder to do the reset. I cannot get up on a ladder, so a visit from my handyman is $90. Other camera models allow setup by Bluetooth. Ring needs to add this feature to their camera models.Update July 2020 - My camera has been offline since February. With CV19 it took till now to get a handy man out to reset the camera so it could be re-paired to my Wifi system. It was suggested to me that I add a second chime-pro for this camera which I did. The second chime pro is literally 12 feet and one wood/siding wall from the camera, but the signal strength is still poor.So the handyman leaves and I decided to see if I could tell which of my chime pro units the camera is connected with. The Ring app does not tell you that! It will allow me to switch it to my wifi network... But to initiate that change, the camera needs to be reset, which means for me ANOTHER HANDYMAN VISIT.This is ridiculous! I am lowering my review. I will not purchase another Ring product. These devices are Handicapped UNFRIENDLY.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2020

Review Text: When I read the specifications on this camera I interpreted it as having the same abilities as my flood light camera minus the flood lights. This is incorrect. Review Text: PROS: Sharp video. Email comms. for low battery. CONS: The short mounting bracket meant it is tucked up, under the eaves.
