Review Text: We have hens. I have found it useful to keep a security camera in the coop to be alerted if vermin or predators show up. Over a couple of years we had a couple of wired cameras with the cord stretched across the yard to an outlet, which, in South Florida where we are, pretty quickly got incorporated under the grass and soil as life grew over them. But (our fault), in our situation the cameras shorted out during storms because occasionally the plug-end would come loose, and get wet, and electricity just doesn't work well in that condition. So enough of the wires. It's 2020 for goodness sakes.This model Ring, of course, is wireless, so great! One problem solved. Image in daylight is very clear and wide. Image with night vision, when we really want it, is good, but not A+ best. But good. And the motion detector does notice if something moves through the coop in the night, the test being when one hen moved from her spot on the roost to another spot when the settings were on medium detection. I have boosted the camera to maximum detection to make sure to catch whatever unwelcome little things might skitter through. I'm confident any big things will be noted. I can't WAIT to set off the siren on them.This model Ring is very customizable compared to my other brand of security camera. I like that. It was easy to install (the package even comes with an installation tool). The wifi signal, although across the yard and through concrete walls, gets a solid connection with our modem-router, which I appreciate. The app is straight forward and works well on a Fire Tablet and Android phone. I can't get it to work at all on my PC, however.I might add the solar panel to keep it charged and fuss-free, but even the one battery set (it holds two) holds a charge quite well as I keep turning the Live View on and off, because *new toy*.It's not a perfect security camera. The night vision quality could be improved. And getting the app to work on the PC would be useful. But I like it quite a lot.UPDATE January 2, 2021: I still like it quite a lot, but the condensation in our humid climate was a constant problem, particularly at night. Tip, RainX fixes the problem.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2020

Review Title: One fatal flaw that invalidated the Camera
Review Text: I am a big fan of Ring products. We already have four, across their spectrum of doorbell, floodlight, and indoor ring cams.I will come straight to the point. Review Title: Did a different engineering team design this camera?
Review Text: I recently purchased a Ring 2 doorbell and that has to be one of the easiest and most user friend camera/door bell in existence.  It does everything it was designed to do with no issues whatsoever.Now as far as the Ring spotlight camera (battery), it promises a lot plus if the Ring Doorbell 2 was so great one would expect the spotlight camera to at least be close.  Sorry to say it isn't.  I installed it today (very easy install and directions have me awarding it at least two stars), but everything else is a disappointment.  Here are the issues I have with it:1.  Inconsistent motion detection.  It will detect cars moving on the street, but won't pick anyone walking up the driveway from the sidewalk.  You cannot adjust it out because the only option on the ring spotlight camera (battery) is "sensitivity".  I would think it would pick up movement closer to the camera, but it doesn't.2.  Even excellent wifi coverage (I get usually 35up/125down as that is my work from home requirement for my job) has no affect on the constant "poor signal" warning popping up on the app.  My Ring 2 is on the same side of the house (just further away by about 20 feet) and it gets better reception while being further away from the router. The spotlight camera is less then 5 feet away from the router).3.  When it does managed a motion (like a car 30 feet away) the recording starts when the cars is almost out of the screen.  Car is going 10mph and I have about a 75 front section at my house, but the spotlight camera cannot even get half of the event recorded.  My ring 2 doorbell does a better job and it is at the end of the front of my home (it can record the whole event..well perhaps like 80%...which is still better then the 15% the spotlight records.4.  When bringing up an alert the live view just freezes and never connects.  I have no problem connecting to my Ring 2 and that is further away from the router (that's frustrating).I really wanted to like this camera, but after a whole day of trouble shooting, repositioning the mount on my freshly stuccoed house (not happy with that), tilting the camera up and down...it still has the same issues.  Not sure if this is a bad one or if this is a bad design for a camera.

Review Text: I am not one to ever write and bash a product. In this case, however, I feel it is important to let readers know -especially since many of us use these reviews to make purchasing decisions. This device has been a headache on enough occasions that with the latest issue, I've had enough and have purchased the new camera from Simplisafe, which is already my primary security system.Below are the problems I've experienced since purchasing this system (which had an added solar panel):1) any disruption or change in the internet has resulted in a MINIMUM of an hour, multiple phone calls, and long wait times to resolve. The first person to answer the call always goes through the same process that most of us try before calling (take out battery, reboot, re-do the set up).  When it is clear this won't work (by this time you are already 40 minutes into your call, including wait time, holds, transfers), you are then transferred to the technical people (who you thought you were on hold for in the first place!).The technical person takes you through the same steps again. Then adds a few more. If lucky, the issue is resolved. If not, another call is required, same process, and maybe this time a person answers who can take you through the simple fix, which literally you could have done yourself if the information was available online. By now, you are over an hour on the phone, spending time climbing up and down a ladder (to access the device).2) When the doorbell rings, the ring camera hasn't even notified me that someone is there because there is a big lagtime. In order to see who is at the door, I have to wait until the "live view" fires up. None of the "live view" stuff is recorded. What is the point? On more occasions than I care to count, I've had to go to the door without knowing who is on the other side of it.3) Latest issue: a few weeks ago, recordings and notifications started to stop at 7 PM and do not resume until 6 AM. A call placed to the help line (same process and timing involved as above) ended in "well, you have to call back when the problem is going on". This, after the same 40 minutes spent holding, etc.  Call back?? The very last thing I want to do at 8 PM after a long day of work is haul out my ladder and fiddle around with this device. Bye bye Ring.  By the way, I've tried every solution to this current issue that I was able to find online. It seems to be that  this is a common issue. For me, it just began out of the blue a few weeks ago.  One of the main uses for the camera, as we all know, is to watch the front door.  If this isn't working in the middle of the night, what is the point?Bottom line: do not buy unless you like endless fiddling and long wait times. There are less expensive and better items available.Sorry to rant, but I would want to see this review if I were considering plunking over $250 again. (camera plus solar panel). The new camera I am ordering is 2/3 of the price and has many more options included.

Review Text: I live in a quiet residential neighborhood (all SFH) and every few months vandals pop in and spend a week or two breaking into or stealing cars and then they move on to another neighborhood.I have (wired) security cameras around the house that I really like, but my house is set back from the street and the cameras don’t capture street activity really clearly. So I mounted this Ring camera on a tree about 5-feet from the street.Pros: During the day the clarity is amazing. I can clearly see faces, make/model of cars, and read license plates. The camera is super easy to set up. The app is super easy to use. It has great features (privacy zones, motion schedule, neighborhood sharing, alarm, etc). When a person/car enters the zone at night a bright light turns on, which is a great deterrent.Cons: I currently only have 1 battery pack and it needs to be recharged every 4-5 days. The coverage area has a fair amount of activity (kids playing in the street, people walking dogs, Amazon delivery trucks driving by, etc) but it is a quiet side street in a sleepy residential neighborhood. The camera is mounted up high so dragging a ladder out and dismantling the camera every 4 days is not sustainable, especially if there is snow or ice. Also, it takes 6+ hours to fully charge so for the bulk of the day the camera is out of commission. At night the clarity could be better.I love, love, love everything this camera but it’s just not sustainable for me to recharge the battery every 4-5 days. I’ve just ordered a second battery pack. If that doesn’t significantly extend time between charges I am probably going to return it.

Review Title: Not happy. Night capture mode has lots of issues.  Motion detection is subpar.
Review Text: Night capture mode is terrible. I put the cam up at the corner of my house under the awning, which is not visible in the picture but at night the IR feedback is so bad from surrounding surfaces it over exposes and you can't see much past 10 feet. Someone told me to put tape over the IR lights which worked like a champ, but then the problem is it also covers up the spotlight.  So I had to find a compromise where I covered the IR lights as much as possible and the spotlight as little as possible but since they are tin the same place the IR light bleeds through too much.The second issue is that the motion detection is terrible. For some reason it won't detect a car pulling into the driveway right in front of it, but it will constantly trigger when shadows move on the ground or leaves get in front of it. It also triggers motion alerts on the street even though my zone ends at the side walk. I also found when I come back from my jogs it never even detects me, because I came up to the house too fast?  The settings for this thing are black box and I'm not sure what they really do they just seem to have a mind of their own.  I have tried ever setting, poured over reddit and help forums but it seems like there are only 3 settings to this thing. Capture absolutely everything,  Capture a lot of nothing but occasionally capture something.  Capture absolutely nothing.The other day someone was reeling their dog out to take a crap on my yard it never detected. I saw it because I was in the garage, I went back to history and sure enough it never registered even though it was a person with their legs walking through my motion zone and a dog running around right in front of the camera didn't trigger.  3 minutes later a car drives by... out of my motion zone and it triggers.  I really don't get this thing.  I will not buy another.  The most solid Ring product is the door bell 2nd Gen. Battery life is about 3 weeks which is low but tolerable for how many times it turns on to capture leaves and shadows.

Review Text: I develop properties and I have installed many Ring Spotlight cameras. Most are the hard wired variety, I have a couple that plug in, and I attempted a go at this battery powered one for one of my rentals. It does have the advantage of not needing power to be run to it, but the functionality compared to the others is quite lacking.Let's talk about the differences between this battery unit and the powered ones.A powered cam is recording all the time, and when it senses motion, it will start the archived video a few seconds before the motion is sensed. That means you'll see the mailman get out of his truck and walk up to the door to drop the mail, all very clear. The battery powered one waits till it sees motion, then boots up and starts recording, so you see the mailman closing the mailbox and walking away. You never see his face. I mean that's fine for the mailman but if it's a robber you've just missed your chance to identify the person. It's also fuzzy for the first half second, so you miss that time as well.The motion zone function is gimped compared to the powered cams. You can select from three motion zones, but you cannot adjust the distance. This works fine in a doorway or walkway where you have a limited area that people will be walking in, but it won't cover a back yard or a driveway. You have to wait until the person gets up to the door before it will sense the motion. In the powered spotlight cam, you can select the motion zone precisely, and set it for far longer distances.Not to say this is a poor product. Ring's software is great, the kit is very complete with tools, mounting hardware, etc. Everything works well and is of high quality. Battery life is as good as they say, with a good wi-fi connection 6 months is totally possible. However, if you have any way to run power I would very much recommend upgrading to the plug in or "mount" hardwire spotlight cam as they work far better.

Review Text: I’ve had this camera for about 2 1/2 years.  The first problem I have with all my outside cameras ( I also have 3 floodlight cameras) is the latency issue. When the cameras pick up motion there is a 7 to 8 second delay before it sends a notification to my IPhone or my IPad or any of the Alexa devices I use so when someone pulls into my driveway there at my door before I get notified so don’t count on them to save your life if that’s what you’re looking for.  This battery powered camera I have over my driveway and I have way too many connection problems with it when I’m trying to use it, I’d say about 50% of the time I can’t pull up a live view when I want to. I have Comcast gig internet and the camera is no more 30 feet away. Review Text: Works pretty well. I wanted to highlight two things: like others, I promptly lost the set screw that tightens the collar on the mount so the camera doesn’t move or fall off. Learn from my mistake - go to the official Ring store and for $1.99 you can buy a spare parts package that contains the collar and screw. That would have been far easier and cheaper. Second learning is about the WiFi. I put it overlooking our pool on the outside eaves and it was choppy, didn’t work, and bad sound. I bought the Chime Pro and put it on the wall inside the house by the camera, solved the issue. Once the Chime Pro is set up via the app, i thought it would automatically connect and it didn’t. I found you have to go into the camera advanced settings directly and switch the network to be the Chime instead of my WiFi. Once I did that, it worked perfectly and the quality is great. Like others, the volume on the camera needs to be louder - you cannot hear unless standing right by it, but all in all we are happy. Review Title: Missing event video (and it just happens to be a break-in)
Review Text: I have had my Ring spotlight cam for a year now and have found having it comforting, although fortunately any real need to have it hasn't occurred. Until today. A burglar entered our residence through the front door. We confronted her in the act of stealing laptops, she had been outside our house in the morning and entered into it when the door was left temporarily unlocked. Fortunately one of us was home and upon encountering her after hearing the door open, she dropped the laptops she was trying to steal and left the house. We called the police shortly thereafter and they were able to apprehend the thief.The police asked us to check the Ring for the video evidence. To my surprise, there was all the video after the thief came in, including the police coming, and there was video taken prior from the night before, but no video of the actual thief entering the house. WTF?!? The one time we really needed the Ring for its intended purpose, and it failed.I then chatted with Ring support to see if it was possible to retrieve it, and was told no, if it didn't register . as a motion triggered event, no video was recorded nor retrievable. The rep pointed the finger at it being a slow internet connection to the Ring, and that this could cause some videos to not be recorded. Hmm, ok, then how come I've never gotten any error message or warning that this was a potential issue for the past year I've had this and expected it work as promised?"Oh, because we can only see connectivity issues on our side and the end user can't see them." So apparently I've had a faulty Ring going for over a year and it takes an actual robbery attempt to discover this? If this product is going to be less than 100% reliable and as an end user, I'm not actually going to be aware of when it is not, then it's value as a security camera is nil. I'm also not sure I totally buy this reason, as I have so many other recorded events, including all the ones immediately after and before. This is the only video that I am aware of being missing, of course I haven't really had to track all the times it was just me or my wife leaving the house, or the mail man coming.Anyways, if you can't count on a security camera working perfectly and there's no way to know if it's not working (when it appears to be working), then it's not something I can recommend in good faith. It took an actual attempted robbery to learn this the hard way, hopefully you'll be smart and look for a more secure, fail-proof solution.

Review Title: Good cam, gets the job done, easy to setup.
Review Text: I received this on Saturday, a day earlier than what was showing in tracking (good job Amazon!). My son and I went to work and started setting things up. Having worked with Ring devices before for clients, it was exciting to set one up for my home. It all worked out well, and setup was a breeze.I was thinking this product would support 5ghz wireless, but only 2.4ghz. Not a deal breaker but just shows they're probably working on a 3rd gen one of these things which might support 5ghz. Either way, it works well for me, signal is strong, and the picture is clear. The only thing that was a pain in the butt was setting up the motion zones. After messing with it for 2 days, I ended up foregoing the gutter mount bracket that I bought, and mounted it to the brick. Do yourself a favor and get your own masonry bit as the one they send you is dull as all hell. The reason I mounted it to the brick is because of the height. While it was at the recommended 9 feet, I wasn't capturing what I wanted to on the driveway, and got more alerts for cars going by. Not a big deal, switched it to alert for people only and that quieted down the alerts a bit.It wasn't triggering very well, so I moved it lower so it could capture a wider area. I did this per the Ring instructions and recommendations. However, you'll need to keep one thing in mind about the app. Setting up motion zones is weird, and according to them, they're working on it. The way you do it is by turning the zone ON or OFF, in the app. Then, you click continue, and it gives you a sensitivity bar, but its not really clear what adjusting that bar does in the instructions. Basically what that adjustment bar does in the 2nd step of the motion zone setup, is adjust the distance. Setting it to MAX allows it to sense motions up to 30 feet away. However, there is correlation between how many feet it will detect at, and the position on the adjustment bar. You just have to play around with it until you get it right.... time consuming, and could easily be fixed by a UI update in the app.You apparently could do this before, but they took away the ability to set motion zones precisely in the latest app update. They said its by design, but I think they might "fix" it in a future update. Right now I set my camera to MAX or 3/4 of the way to MAX, and it seems to detect what I want to detect.Battery life seems OK, but I've been doing a lot of adjusting over the last couple of days, and I'm at 75%. Once I get everything adjusted, I won't be messing with it as much and I expect the battery to last a few weeks. Either way, I'll be purchasing the solar panel to keep it charged. I did not buy a 2nd battery, nor do I plan to.Overall, good product. Loses one star for no 5ghz support and pain in the butt motion zone setup. Either way you won't be disappointed.Finally, the subscription. People complain about it, but I don't see what the big deal is here. 3$ per device, or 10$ for an entire location, per month. That a fraction of what I paid when I had a system bought from a security company. Sure, it misses some features, and you get what you pay for with a security company (I originally was going to get a CPI security system until I saw Ring). But, if you don't really care about all of that fancy monitoring and just want something you can setup yourself and pay a marginal monthly fee, you won't be disappointed with Ring in my opinion. For us, devices are nice, features are what I'm looking for, and the price fits my budget.I plan on getting a solar panel for the camera as it seems to be chomping through the battery (probably because I keep screwing around with it), the doorbell cam 3, and an 8 piece security system.

Review Title: horrible battery life - unsuitable for indoor use, no integration with alarm system, no control!
Review Text: I bought these just before the new StickUp camera came out. At that time, the spotlight cam was advertised as being suitable for both indoor and outdoor use. After my experience, I complained to Ring and their customer service agent told me that these cameras are not appropriate for indoor use because you can't control them with either the base alarm system (e.g., turn them on/off depending on whether your security system is armed) or by schedule (e.g., only on at night). In fact, you can't turn them off at all except by removing the battery (or letting it die, as I did). If you want those features, don't buy this product.I bought three of them to cover areas of my house, and installed one. After fully charging the battery (took >7 hours), I gave it a go. Since it was rapidly draining the battery (even without using the lights at all, it was recording video about every 5 minutes through the day and a couple times an hour all night), I put all the settings to as minimal as possible (helped a little with battery life but lost the sensitivity to detect motion in most of the room). It still drained the battery in about 8 days. Even if I used both battery compartments, I'd be dragging in a ladder a couple times a month and having significant downtime for recharging the battery packs. I'm sure this is fine if you want to monitor an area that has zero non-criminal activity, but if you (or your pets, kids, or guests) regularly walk through the field of view, be prepared for the battery to drain super fast and not have any control over settings that would mitigate that. And since there is no integration with the base station, there's absolutely no advantage to sticking with Ring products for this application. I'm trying to decide if there's somewhere I can still use these but I think I will be returning them. I'm really disappointed.

Review Text: My review, after about 3 weeks of use, covers the Ring Spotlight Camera (battery) (I purchased three) and a Ring Chime. I also purchased three, non-Ring, solar panels that I don’t review here. First thing after reading the instructions was to charge the batteries using the USB computer connection. It took about 10 hours per battery to get the indication for a fully charged battery.Next I went online to download the Android software. First, let me say, the Amazon ratings for the cameras were quite good, which led me to make the purchase. I was disappointed to see the Ring software rating to be 3 stars.I checked the MS Windows app. Which was 2.5 stars, and finally the iPad app, which was rated 3 stars. Not really impressive.Mostly thin plastic, the overall construction appears cheap. The battery cover door and latch seem quite fragile and there are no rubber seals. I question the weatherproofing and long-term durability.I first tried the initial set-up using an iPad, it failed with about six attempts. Set-up with Android went rather smoothly (I have no idea why the iPad failed).Mounting: Make sure to review all the entire instructions before starting. There are a couple of things you might miss to make your life easier (e.g., double ended screwdriver, or the reversible mounting plate).All three of my cameras are mounted under the eaves, but, one unit, I’ve moved multiple times, on the same wall, due to the night vision being extremely “washed out”, whereas the image appears as if it were in a dense fog. After some experimentation I found that the issue seems to be from heat being retained into the evening by the wall and being detected by the infrared sensors. I finally moved the camera down lower, where there is less effect from that heat.Back to the software (where most of the issues arise). After everything was physically mounted, I went to the software. The downloaded Owner’s Manual provides very little detail and does not fully match what you’re seeing on the actual app. Getting around in the app was not intuitive at all, went to many a dead-end trying to find my way.  Worse, the online HELP.  Instead of having product specific help, they combine instructions for multiple products on the same page, making things quite confusing at times. Like the Owner’s Manual, often the names of functions are different than what I’m actually seeing on the app.I have an ongoing issue with my primary device, an Android phone. It is not uncommon at all for this device to NOT receive a Motion Alert. For some, yet to be determined, reason the setting keep changing (apparently on their own). Multiple times a day I have to go in and reactivate my motion alerts. Other times, the setting appear fine but it does not receive any alerts.I remounted all of my cameras multiple times in order to cut down on false alerts. After some time, I’ve two cameras giving only minimal false alerts. One last camera, mounted at about 8’ high, is alerting on vehicles, abut 80-100’ away, on the opposite side of a 6’ solid brick wall, the camera can only see the top of those vehicles. I’m still trying different setting with the two Motion Zone adjustments.Motion Schedule: The problem with this setting is that there is nothing to indicate if your settings are activating or deactivating the alerts (i.e., should I select 8:00 a.m. does it stop or start at that time?) The online instructions read, “Set the start and end times”, no help there.  I was able to activate the Motion Schedule but when I can’t get a Schedule to turn off, via the designated “button”; the only way I’ve been able to deactivate a schedule is to actually DELETE it.On the Android, shutting off “Vibrate” also shuts off the sound alertsAfter days of use I discovered many more issues with the software which is too much to go into here. Basically, the software needs considerable improvements to be worthy of the current cost.About a week after setting up my cameras I received an unsolicited email from Ring titled “Optimizing Your Motion Alerts”, these instructions covered three of their products BUT NOT THE ONE I OWN.Overall, the cameras provide good video, day and night. The cameras are of flimsy construction. The mounting hardware not very versatile but usable. The major weakness is in the heart of the system, the software and software manual. Too many false notifications, like Pablov’s dog, encourages you to ignore most of the notifications… which defeats the primary reason for having the system. The other significant issue, is with my Android phone that needs the software “reset”, currently on a daily basis, where as it stops providing Motion Alerts. Does this system make me feel my home is secure? Not really. This being my fist video security system I have nothing to compare it to, but for what I paid, I don’t feel I got my money’s worth.

Even with the camera 5 ft from the router for troubleshooting purposes - we couldn't get it to work. I was asked to connect the device to a second network. Review Text: Loved the idea of a spotlight combined with a motion camera.  I set this up to watch my cars in my driveway.  I've had 2 car break ins in the last year.  My hope was to scare the crook away with the light popping on, before they broke into my car.  Unfortunately, it was a failure.  No matter the zone and sensitivity settings, it was very poor at detecting people.  I'd approach the cam straight on from the edge of my driveway, which was about 25.5' away for testing.  I would be 6-10' away, in front of the cam, with my arms raised above my head, waiving them about, and it would not detect me even 50% of the time.  It was great at catching cars driving by.  After messing with the settings for over 2 weeks, and seeing no improvement, I called their help line.  I was on the phone for 45 minutes with them.  They were attentive and did try to help my adjust the settings, or aim the camera up or down, but nothing improved it.  I was told that the height I had it at was fine, so that was not the issue.  I was told that a specialist would call me the next night at a time I designated.  No one called the next night.  At that point I returned it.  Ring was easy to work with, and accepted the return (it was just a day under the 30 day return window).  The battery life was OK.  Not great.  The battery lasted about 2-3 weeks before needing a recharge.  The shorter battery life than expected could have been due to me changing the settings repeatedly every other day or so.  The wifi was OK.  It claimed it was a weak signal, but rarely disconnected.  I tested the same location with my phone and average about 25 Mb/s.  It's too bad, as I had high hopes for this cam.

Review Title: Poor instructions, complicated set-up, too many issues - WOULD NOT RECOMMEND!
Review Text: I had high hopes for this camera.  We have Wyze cams which we are extremely happy with that we use indoors as doggie cams, but we needed one to monitor the outside of our home.  As Wyze does not yet make a cam for outdoor use, we choose to go with the Ring Spotlight Cam, purchasing the separate solar panel so that we don't have to bother with constantly charging the battery.  BIG MISTAKE!  Unlike the Wyze which takes less than 2-minutes to set up, the instructions for the Ring Spotlight camera set-up are complicated, confusing and inadequate, especially when trying to combine the cam with the solar panel set-up.  One of the steps needed to set up the camera is to slide off a back panel and reverse it for some reason - a step NOT covered in the instructions.  I wound up having to call their customer service department.  A half hour later, I got someone overseas who was working off of a script - which is maddening.  When I was finally able to get her to understand my difficulties, she kept having to put me on hold for each step to consult with someone else.  Another half hour later, she finally gave up and transferred me to someone in the States.  This customer service rep was very professional and tried to assist me, however after we succeeded in setting up the camera, he was unable to get the motion alerts feature to work properly  meaning that while the live cam worked fine, the camera was not sending me any alerts when it detected motion.  After yet another half hour, he said that they would send me a replacement camera.  He said they would include a label for me to send the problematic camera back.  My bad that I forgot to ask a timeframe or tracking info or whether or not they were going to send me packaging for the return cam nor where I was going to have to bring it.  I sent an email to Ring customer support asking all of those questions and kept getting annoying, irrelevant boilerplate responses back, all ending by telling me "we treat our customers like neighbors and genuinely care...".  Sounds real nice, but given that I am now 7 email exchanges in with customer service trying to get answers to my questions, I wouldn't want to be a  Ring neighbor and I don't think they care very much.  I definitely do NOT recommend this particular camera and if someone at Ring is bothering to read this - you really need to improve both your set-up instructions AND your customer support.  STOP with the annoying boiler plate responses and tell your customer support people to actually take two minutes to read and respond to the email that is sent!UPDATE AUGUST 13TH:  Okay - I have to update my initial one-star review detailing my horrendous experience trying to get this camera working and my subsequent frustration with customer service both on the phone and in endless email exchanges which were not addressing my outstanding issues and questions.  Today I had a call with Alexis from Ring whose title I believe is "Amazon Executive Community Support Representative."  Alexis made up for most of what I had gone through with Ring customer service to date.  She was everything you could hope for in a customer service rep.  1) She is located in the USA, speaks fluent English and was definitely not working off of some boiler plate script.  Please don't call me xenophobic - dealing with overseas call centers can be - and was for me - absolutely maddening and unproductive.  Dealing with someone in the USA who was capable of thinking outside of a prescribed box was, by comparison, a pleasure.  2) Alexis had researched and was aware of my previous experiences with customer service and was extremely apologetic and sympathetic - much appreciated.  3)  She listened carefully to what had gone wrong with the first Ring cam I was sent and patiently walked me through setting up the replacement cam - step-by-step, carefully explaining everything we were doing and how everything works as well as patiently answering all of my many questions.  Had I dealt with Alexis or someone as professional and helpful as she is from the beginning, I would have fewer gray hairs and lower blood pressure.  I have upgraded my rating from one star to two in recognition of my positive experience with Alexis, but I cannot give this product 5 stars due to the problems I had with the first cam, my subsequent experiences with customer service, and the problems I continue to have with the replacement cam.UPDATE ON SEPT 5, 2019:  So the problems with this camera don't seem to end.  First, the reception was poor and the camera was not picking up motion or sending alerts.  Alexis in Customer Service I told me to re-locate the cam, which I did.  The problem persisted.  Still dealing with Customer service rep Alexis (I can no longer count how many phone calls and emails back-and-forth), she ultimately wound up sending me a Chime Pro booster to boost the signal from my router to the cam, which was very nice of her - but why should that even have been necessary to make this cam function properly?  I had to relocate the Chime Pro four times before finding an outlet that actually helped boost the poor signal the cam was getting.  Again - bear in mind we have two Wyze cams, much further from the router and on a different floor that have NO problem with the signal.  With the Chime Pro, the cam was picking up a better signal from the router, but still missing  a good amount of the action in front of it and missing sending alerts for that action.  Not much more customer service could do or recommend to resolve that issue.Today, I looked for a way to record live action on the cam and found there is none.  You'd think that a security camera would have a simple button on the live action screen that you could push to immediately record the action taking place - not the Ring Cam.  I contacted Alexis once again asking her how I could accomplish this.  In her first response, Alexis wrote back "Once the live video finishes (or you click the red phone icon to end it yourself) you can share the event through event history in the Ring App. There are icons in the bottom right corner that allow you to download (to your mobile device), email, share directly to neighbors, text message, etc. the video file to whomever you'd like (or yourself)."I responded that this is not what I asked, needed or wanted.  I was looking for a way to record live action as it was occurring, not a way to share one of the brief "motion alerts" that the cam periodically sends and saves.  Alexis then wrote back:  "Yes, Apple allows screen recording: https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT207935."  Wonderful.  So the answer to the question is that the Ring Cam has NO way to easily record live action.  BIG design flaw!  So consider this scenario: your car is being broken into in the driveway and - if you're lucky - the cam will pick up the action and send you a motion alert.  You turn on the live cam and see the perpetrator breaking into your car.  You want to record the video to capture what is happening so that you can provide it to law enforcement.  No  way to do that with the Ring cam.  You have to follow some convoluted instructions to go through your cel phone's settings.  I actually tried to do this and even that didn't work at recording the live action on the cam screen.BOTTOM LINE:  First I was sent a defective camera which, after hours on the phone, was ultimately replaced (I had to schlep the defective cam to UPS to return it).  Set-up on the new cam was not "plug and play" as it is for Wyze cams.  Set-up was difficult and complicated.  Reception was poor and I had to uninstall and reinstall the camera in a different location to try to improve the signal.  Signal still poor, Alexis - in Ring Customer Service who - as I have said a number of times - was very nice and really tried to resolve all these issues - sent me a Chime Pro signal booster.  After much moving around, finally found a place where the Chime Pro did succeed in boosting the signal from the router to the cam.  The cam continues to miss much of the motion going on in front of it and I only get some of the motion alerts but it is definitely better than before, for what that's worth.Wanting to record live action, I discovered the cam has no feature to do this - that I have to follow some convoluted process through my iPhone.As hard as Alexis has tried to assist me - there are way too many issues with this Ring cam and it has occupied way too much of my time attempting to resolve them.I would not only NOT recommend this Ring cam - I would say avoid it at all costs and seek alternatives.My Wyze cams are much easier in every way and do a much better job and if they had one suitable for outdoor use, I would buy it in a heartbeat.

Review Title: Great camera, but app  software needs improvement
Review Text: Very nice camera—easy to install, very good image in HD, but needs a strong WiFi signal to connect.  I added the solar panel and the battery never goes below 80%.I had to add an access point in my house, even though I had a Ring Chime/repeater 25 feet away.Some software issues (iPhone app):1.  I also have a Ring Pro doorbell (purchased first).  That has a very flexible motion zone (i.e., the area where motion will activate the chime).  You can creat a custom area to monitor.  Unfortunately, the ability to adjust the motion zone for the camera is very restricted. Basically, you can select from left-center-right thirds (1, 2 or all 3) and distance (near to far).  Our camera faces down our driveway, and every time the wind blows through our rose bushes, the chime goes off.  The doorbell has a motion sensitivity option and the ability to exclude the bushes.  The camera (in the app) does not have these options.2.  When installing the camera, the app asks you to name the location from some presets (e.g., “Garage”).  However, when set off, the announcement just says “Motion at Spotlight Camera”.  I don’t know how you would differentiate if you had two or more.  Since I had to select a name, I would like the notification to say “Motion at Garage Spotlight Camera.”3.  When there is motion, I’m notified almost instantly.  However, if I want to see what’s happening, I have to open the Ring app, select the camera, then tap “Live” and wait 5-10 seconds to see the image. Usually, the delivery person or whoever is gone by the time the camera is activated in live mode. (However, a 30 second replay is available in a few minutes.)So, great camera with app software and responsiveness to a request for “live” video that needs improvement. (If you are listening, Ring, you can start queuing “live” video as soon as the motion detector goes off.)

Review Title: Does not meet expectations at all.
Review Text: This product is relatively straightforward to install and the experience of initial setup is pretty well done. This earned them 1 star. The video is very clear, the night vision is as well, and the light + siren is a nice feature. Star #2.This is unfortunately where the benefits end for me. This product requires an active subscription for some of the most important features to stay available to you; saving recordings of motion events. Now, the do mention the protection plans on this product page, however I feel that the text is the bare minimum. They do not mention to you that you will not be able to access or save any records, regardless of being 30 days old or 30 seconds old. Honestly, I expected better but in the word of MRR/ARR it doesn't surprise me that this company has found a way to charge us a recurring charge. $10 per month for a household or $3 for device is not steep but it was unexpected because it is NOT EXPLICITLY STATED that you cannot save recordings without it. I have the ability to store the data and would be happy to set that up but there's no way to DIY. You either pay for their service or you get nothing.Additionally, it's a pain in the rear to get signed up for this service. The only way to do it is to select to do so via the prompts you get after you enjoy a 30 day trial. You can't get it to go through any other means that I have found.My biggest complaint however is the seemingly random issues that are encountered with streaming live. The camera sits outside mounted 6 feet from an exterior wall. On the other side of that exterior wall is a router that I can only describe as complete overkill. I bought an insanely fast router with large signal range (3200 Sq Ft. on the 2.4 ghz band) and I still encounter the "STREAMING ERROR" notification 90% of the time I try to access the camera. Funnily enough this started only AFTER my 30 day trial to their service ended. Hm.I have found a way to make this camera useful without their support service via the If This Then That application. You can link the camera to your HUE lights so when it detects motion from 10p - 7a I have set it to turn on lights in various locations around the house. That's pretty cool, but this is not a feature Ring has created, it's a feature someone created on IFTTT.Disappointed in this purchase, will eventually be upgrading away from this device and manufacturer into one that allows me to handle the storage better and doesn't have unending STREAMING ERRORs.

Review Title: How To Turn A 5-Star Device Into A 3-Star Device
Review Text: HOW, you wonder is that done? By scrimping big-time on the battery. First and foremost, there is no battery charger in the box, only a cable to attach the battery to a charger. All the little manual in the box says is: “First fully charge the battery by plugging it into a power source using the provided orange cable. “  On the Ring website, it says; ”Your Spotlight Cam battery is charged using a common micro-USB cable (an orange one is included in your Ring box). The micro-USB cable can be plugged into any USB power source such as a computer. Your battery will take around five to 10 hours to fully charge depending on whether the USB cable is plugged into a USB port or into a wall outlet.”  So, if you don’t just happen to have a charging cube that takes a removable USB cable, you’ll have to charge it through your laptop. Good luck with that because it took me more than 8 hours to charge the battery when I plugged it into a wall outlet with a charger I happened to have—I started around 3 p.m., and it was still charging when I went to bed at 11 p.m. but ready in the morning. That’s the second big-time battery scrimp by Ring. I was really glad I had invested in a second battery, because who wants to have a security camera that goes offline for 5-10 hours every time the battery needs charging?! All this nonsense really put me in a bad frame of mind before I ever saw what the device can actually do. It took 2 stars off this review because the device itself is excellent. I have come back to add this info re the battery: I put in a fully charged battery at 3 p.m. on June 10; at 3 p.m. on June 12, that battery in down to 85%, so it appears that I will be changing the battery about once every 2 weeks.The camera itself is terrific. It provides a crystal-clear color image during the day and a very respectable B&W image at night without any additional light. But if someone is at your door, the spotlight will have activated in response to the motion (says the Ring manual—no one has yet come to my door at night for me to observe this function; I have just looked at the picture at night in the app). I did not enable the HDR video setting that improves video clarity in the daytime because it’s already very clear and the manual says enabling HDR decreases battery life. Talking to someone at the door is automatic—just start speaking. If you have an Echo Show, you can set up the camera to also work with Alexa. I named the camera device FRONT, so all I have to do is say, “Alexa, show me FRONT.” And you can talk to the visitor via the Echo device rather than via your phone: "Alexa, answer FRONT." Its motion sensitivity is almost too good. The camera is at my front door, aimed at the covered porch area, which is a good 25 feet back from the street. I have set the Motion Zone to the minimum allowed, but I still get a motion chirp on my phone anytime a car goes by quickly (slower cars don’t register anymore now that the Zone is minimized). But all large trucks that drive up get a chirp—UPS truck, trash truck, recycling truck, etc. I plan to get a tall friend to help me refine the aim of the camera slightly lower to try and omit seeing cars. But I feel sure that, as long as I have a working battery in place, nothing is going to sneak up on my house from the front! And I might have to put a bag over the camera when the lawn-mowing crew shows up to keep from getting endless chirps on my phone.

Review Text: When I see a review with three stars I tend to fail it in my mind and I probably shouldn't because this product definitely serves its purpose.  But as the headline says, it could be better in some areas, here are the strengths and weaknesses.1.  The motion detection is mostly reliable.  Out of 20 or 30 package deliveries, it only failed to alert once.  However, the unit must put itself to sleep after a long period of inactivity because there is a very long delay between the actual motion and the alert on the app for the first incident.  Subsequent motions however are VERY fast to alert the app.  No matter what though, when you get an alert and tap on Live View, unless the people are hanging around your camera location, you will never catch the delivery person; they'll be gone by the time you're connected and viewing.2.  That brings me to the Event History section on the app.  This is very good and starts recording very quickly.  So when you go back and access this you should be able to catch everything that happened.  It takes a few minutes for that to upload to the server and available for you to watch though, not a big deal.3.  Video Quality:  On your phone it looks great.  But if you ever choose to watch it on a full size computer screen, it's obvious the video is heavily compressed which gives it a grainy, soft focus appearance.  I'm picky about things and wish this was better.  I'm not sure it's even as good as my daughter's dash cam video I've viewed. But again, it's just fine on your phone.4.  Audio Quality:  Frankly not very good.  It has a noise cancellation circuit which I think causes more problems than it solves.  The audio is very noisy.  Anyone remember trying to listen to AM radio back in the 1960s or 70s?  Plus the volume is constantly pumping up and down hunting for the right level depending on what it thinks it is detecting outside.But the worst part is - and maybe my aging Samsung Galaxy S6 is partially to blame - when trying to have a conversation with a person outside, (follow me here) as the person's voice comes through my phone's speaker, their voice then re-enters my phone's mic and plays it back outside through the camera (as if I'm the one talking) and then mutes the person outside - thus - cutting them off after the first three words and making it impossible to hear what they're saying.  Frustrating! 5.  What I really like about it is the wireless (battery operated) unit.  No house-wiring required.  I can't comment on the battery life however because I bought the solar panel to keep it charged and it works GREAT!  I know this isn't a review on the solar panel, but can't recommend this combination enough, very well executed.And the wireless network connectivity works flawlessly as well with (only) the 2.4 Ghz option available.Bottom line is, there are very few units in the market that do what this does without hassling with house wiring and for that reason, I would definitely buy this camera unit again.

Review Title: Does not work in cold weather
Review Text: WINTER UPDATE: I have downgraded this device from five stars to one stars. The batteries do not work when it is below 32F. This camera worked great in the summer and hasn't worked since November. And since I bought it in May, it's too late to return it. Now I have a fancy brick sitting on my garage door.If you live in a cold climate, get the hardwired cam!! I wish I had known this before I bought it!Original Review:We set this camera by my detached garage. Unfortunately it was far enough from our home router that it didn't get much signal. The camera would connect to the app but it wouldn't work - any motion caputred videos were plain black. I then ordered TP-Link AC1200 Wireless MU-MIMO Gigabit Indoor/Outdoor Access Point (EAP225-Outdoor). I ran an Ethernet cable from my router, out my basement window and to the TP Link Access point. I mounted the access point on the outside of my house that faces the garage to create a strong outdoor wifi signal. Only after that the camera worked, and it worked really well! Within one day of use, the camera already caught some action. Some kids used my driveway to turn around on their scooter. And at night, we caught a cat checking out our car. I am so happy I finally have eyes on that side of my house!

Review Title: Revised Review Happier with Wired Version vs Battery camera
Review Text: Update 5/12/20:I was contacted by an Amazon Ring Technical Support Representative after my initial review on the battery powered camera. This person was truly interested in making sure I was happy with my purchase. After several phone calls troubleshooting I have found that the wired version of this Ring camera is better suited to my internet/placement situation. I initially did not purchase the wired version because it meant drilling a hole in my garage, but after many attempts to adjust the wifi and camera settings the Ring Support Representative sent me a Chime Pro and then eventually the wired version of the camera. The representative was knowledgeable (even about my Orbi mesh system), friendly, and responsive. I feel that they have gone above and beyond and truly exceeded my expectations on helping me with the problems I was experiencing. There is still occasionally some delay between receiving a notification on my phone and pulling up the live video, but it is much, much better and I would recommend for folks that have issues with the live view/streaming to reach out to Amazon Ring support (not the Ring support general number) to get help.Initial Review: I have a ring doorbell and purchased this camera to add extra security to an area of our yard/house that we can't see. Right from the beginning I have had problems. It installed fine but live view would not work consistently on the camera (works fine on doorbell). So I searched support and decided that it could be my internet. So I purchased another Orbi satellite to install near the camera. The signal is excellent according to the Ring app. But I still had a problem. Review Title: Motion detection is less sensitive at the normal direction then sideways in both light and camera
Review Text: The motion detection for light is not sensitive in the center. A person walking from left or right side can be detected in reasonable distances. However, if I walk toward the camera from the center, the camera light doesn't turn on until I am very close to the camera. Both the light and the camera have a obvious higher motion detection sensitivity at left and right sides than at center direction.Ring Floodlight Cam has a cool feature to draw a motion detection zone defined by 5 or 6 points, but this feature is not available in this Spotlight Cam. I installed the camera at 8 feet high (1 foot higher than recommendation) above my garage door. No matter how I adjusted the angle of the camera (I set motion detection sensitivity and frequency to max), it  always started recording video a little bit late and missed the most critical moment.Bad packaging: a camera lens is normally pasted with a thin plastic film to protect the lens from scratching. However, this camera doesn't. I thought I might receive a used one. And also because of bad motion detection, I requested a replacement. Then I compared motion of two cameras. They are very different. One is dramatically worse than the other in detecting a person walking from the center (the Normal plane).One factor that I like about the product is the light. It is very bright.

Review Text: I researched the various systems and decided to go with Ring.  It’s affordable, they offer a variety of products and it’s easy to install. If ever I don’t want the notification, it can be turned off. The range is great and can be easily adjusted from your phone. I started with one unit to see if I would be satisfied with the product. Review Title: Great battery option, motion detection setup could be better.
Review Text: Does an adequate job of capturing activity but the motion detection options are lacking compared to the wired spotlight and floodlight cameras I have.  I understand this is due to trying to conserve battery life, but I’m still struggling with either getting too much activity (cars passing by) or not enough (people almost out of frame before recording starts).  The controls allow you to turn on/off three zones in front of the camera and adjust the distance in which it is detecting motion using a slider. Unfortunately this ends up with a lot of guess work in setting up detection zones.  If the ability to set motion zones via live picture was there similar to the wired versions this would make tuning recordings much easier.It helps being able to link this camera to the others so it starts recording when my front door or driveway cameras detect motion, but it does eat into battery life.  Having two batteries does seem to help, and adding the aftermarket solar panel in direct sunlight definitely helps and keeps everything fully charged.  Decided to go the battery and solar panel option since I didn’t have good options for running power to this side of the house.The LED lighting is adequate, although not extremely bright, for a battery model is more than what I expected.  Illuminates the immediate area and provides adequate lighting for the camera view to show what's setting off the movement detection.  The night vision is okay at best, but its hard to tell whats going on outside of what's directly in front of the camera not illuminated by the IR.No issues connecting with my wifi router.  This camera is located outside the house about 50ft from where my router sits and has a very strong signal.The siren isn't  blaring loud, but I think enough to call attention to the surrounding area when manually activated.  I've used it to scare off a skunk and it worked well for that purpose.Overall, I’m happy with the outcome but hoping that Ring continues to improve the motion detection options on the battery model.  The battery model  is certainly a good option when not having a good wired power source, but I do recommend installing with a solar panel.

Review Title: Thank u, next. UPDATED: gets worse over time.
Review Text: I bought the Ring last year and have given it about eight months. Every time I try a new solution, it disappoints me. As you can read from other reviews, the video takes forever to load, so unless you pay for the video storage service, you probably won’t see the thing that set off your ring. It seems like a scam to force you to pay for the monthly video storage, else it’s useless to set up alerts.  Even when you try to get the live feed to check-in on your property, it’s a 50-50 chance your app will connect to the device at all.Let’s say you pay for the storage service... you’re lucky if the thing even goes off.  I can walk straight at it or approach it at an S-curve, and it won’t pick me up. I can even wave my hand in front of it, and nothing. Pull into the driveway - not a flinch. Yet occasionally, it’ll throw an alert when I leave my house/walk past it (rarely - maybe 4% of the time). Updating or reinstalling the app fixes most issues... for a day or two. Review Title: Great for locations without access to electrical wiring
Review Text: I purchased this to sit above my front door.  The way my house is constructed, a doorbell camera is not feasible, so I decided to try this camera.  Additionally, there was no easy way to wire the camera without unsightly easy to tamper with exposed wires.  I also purchased a second battery with the camera to ensure no down time.The camera was easy to install, and reside above my front door.  I have it set to it's most sensitive settings (i.e. highest battery drain).  The camera has been in place a month now and the battery is at 50 % now.  The second battery is still at 100% (when two batteries are present, the camera runs on one and holds the second in standby.  It will switch to the second battery once the first is nearly flat.)Pro's* Easy to install* Can be installed anywhere, no wiring required* Good quality video / sound* Decent battery life* Spotlight lights up my entrance way very well* Based on my current settings (most sensitive) large insects flaying near-by have activated the motion alerts (For me this is a plus, as I know a person will definitely activate it)* Ability to have two batteries so no downtimeCon's* Camera is in standby mode until motion is detected so no pre-recording* Camera takes a second to start up recording once motion is detected* Inconsistent motion activation* 4-6 hour battery charge timeOverall, if you have an area you would like a camera, but don't have easy access to wiring / don't want to run wiring this is a great alternative.  I would recommend spending the money on the solar panel and/or a second battery.  Do to the long recharge time a second battery allows for no downtime as the camera automatically switches from the flat battery to the charged one allowing you to remove it and recharge it as needed.  The solar panel can keep a battery topped off with just a few hours of sunlight daily.In short, I will be purchasing 1-2 more Spotlight Battery and 2-3 more Spotlight Wired to complete my camera setup at my house.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2019

Review Title: SUPER Happy with Ring Wireless Spotlight Cam!
Review Text: A few weeks ago, I was involved in a serious police incident involving an armed trespasser. He forced entry into a condo owned by my 78 year old mother. I own a condo in the same complex in a good neighborhood. He used a crow bar on the door but then he closed and locked the same door once he was inside the condo, so it truly appeared like an unsuccessful forced entry attempt to unsuspecting people like me and my sister. She and I were about to unlock and open the door when we decided to call the police instead. Little did we know, the trespasser was on the other side of the door ..... with a loaded 9mm handgun, a large hunting knife, and an unloaded AR15. The only thing that kept us from walking in on him and his weapons was a split second of common sense. Once the police investigation was done and the adrenaline wore off, the first thing I thought about was security and the very next thing I thought about was Ring.I ordered Ring via Prime and it was delivered next day. Everything about Ring is AMAZING. The set-up and installation were engaging and simple. I love being able to access options and modify settings via the Ring app and website from anywhere and anytime. The cam is tucked into the eave over my front door so it's barely noticeable. The footage and image clarity is awesome. I can share footage with friends and family and link them to my camera as added users. The motion detection zone and alerts and everything is customizable to perfectly fit your needs and preferences. The Ring Neighborhood community is another benefit, keeping people in your area involved and aware of what's going on in your vicinity. Review Title: Great system! Only one complaint so far
Review Text: We recently had a break in to our car and my wallet and my kids belongings were stolen- it happened within a 15 minute window and immediately after dealing with this we ordered this camera. (With extra battery included)We live on a fairly busy street in a condo complex, wiring a camera just wasn’t an option so we settled for this. So far, it’s been great. For how busy our street is, it picks up nearly every car driving by on the street (which I dont mind), one battery we put in at 100% and the other was around 60-65% and in 4 days with a lot of people coming and going and the cars passing by the battery level has dropped down to 48% and the other is still at 100%. We even caught our postman skipping our place completely and marking our address ‘undeliverable’.PROS: Super easy install, captures everything in crisp clear detail, night feature you can have night vision on only (to save battery) or have the motion detected light turn on, you can hear EVERYTHING and the talk back and alarm features work well and are extremely loud, you can adjust the range of where exactly you want motion to be detected and has quite the range and great sensitivity (which also can be changed based on how often you want to be alerted)CONS: WiFi Range, we had to purchase the TPLINK 750 WiFi extender in order to get a proper connection and signal. We don’t live in that big of a place so the fact that the WiFi signal was so poor was kind of a bummer. That’s literally the only reason I gave it 4 stars.FWIW; I see a lot people complaining about battery life and honestly, it’s to be expected with how much goes on in our neighborhood. I wouldn’t expect the battery life to diminish NEAR as quick at all on a private residence. Would definitely purchase the extra battery and keep a close eye on the battery to stay ahead of both batteries dying at the same time. (And the battery charges in about an hour)

So I was forced to sign up, $30 was not too bad at all. However, we realized that some one had been on our property messing with the irrigation ditch in the front yard. Water rights are a big deal in this county and some one trespassing on my property is an even bigger deal. I started scrolling through the Ring activity log yesterday and none of the videos would come up. I work in a busy clinic and did not get a chance to keep up with alerts. When I contacted customer service via chat, her name was Linda, she offered me no help at all. She said the videos were not accessible and we should have signed up sooner. How about ring being more up front with what "upgrade" means. So, basically you have to pay an annual fee for the camera to function properly. How about Ring state that instead of offering an upgrade. I am so mad. I have no idea who was on my property (rural) while I was 50 minutes away at work. I bought this for security, for the motion alerts, and for peace of mind. I am so disappointed. I will be returning the camera and cancelling the service.

Review Title: Cheap Plastic Build Quality, Somewhat Large..Picture Was Sharp and Clear. Other Cameras in market that are better for less monty
Review Text: I really wanted to like this camera. I purchased off the Amazon Treasure Truck so my price was really good upon purchasing. However, when I hooked it up, that's where I began to feel different about the quality of this camera. The build quality is modest at best. It is a LOT of plastic and after inserting the battery and closing the battery compartment I didn't feel as this camera would stand up to the elements mostly rain in a heavy storm. The range on this is terrible. It would record the motion videos but never send the alert to my new Samsung Galaxy S9+. Video quality was better than I expected. Now, I had been using the first ARLO system's cameras for the past 3 years. Although only 720, the cameras did everything else great (in fact better than the Ring Spotlight camera). Build quality on the ARLO cameras was excellent and SO much easier to install and setup. No drilling four holds to mount the base and then having to adjust and tighten the camera on a swivel mount. These cameras are also very BIG. More noticeable and stick out much more than the old ARLO cameras I had. Some might feel this is good as a deterrent to crime. The lights on the Spotlight camera system were a nice touch and could be activated manually or set to turn on upon a motion in front of camera automatically at night if you toggle that option in the app. The siren wasn't that loud but for effect it works. Compared to the siren on the ARLO system and I find it better. The alarm on the ARLO is at the base station not on the outside cameras. I don't know about how long the batteries last as I took it down today (the same day I set it up). My bottom line is...if this thing had worked more similarly to the performance of my Ring 2 doorbell it would be a better piece of equipment. I only paid $139.99 for my one camera. After looking at this camera.(too large) and comparing it to others on the market I would never buy another one again.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2018

Review Text: I really, really want to like the Ring products.  When they work well they are fantastic.However, they are very sensitive to the quality of the WiFi signal.  That signal needs to be *extremely* strong in order for Ring products to be functional.I installed the Sportlight Cam approximately 30 feet away from my nearly new Linksys AC2200 router.  There is only 1 wall between the camera and the router.Very close in proximity, but the RSSI within Device Health for this camera in the Ring app is 72 (poor connection).  RSSI is the term Ring used to measure the signal health.  Ring support says that number should ideally be in the mid 40’s to low 50’s.What does it take to get your RSSI to that, or lower?  I have a Ring Doorbell Pro that I was having signal strength issues with as well.  Support send me a a Ring Chime to help resolve the issues.  A Ring Chime is pretty much just a WiFi extender.I have my Ring Chime installed about 4’ (yes, 4 feet) from my Doorbell Pro and am getting an RSSI of 36.  These products seem to almost have to be right on top of your router (or WiFi extender) to work properly.This isn’t feasible and, in many cases, isn’t possible.  I don’t have an outlet available near where the Spotlight cam needs to go.If I have to install a WiFi extender for each Ring product that I install (which is what it is looking like would have to happen), then I’m probably dealing with the wrong product.

Review Title: Images show one design and you actually get another but got resolved
Review Text: The design is NOT what is consistently shown. The primary connection, video unit to mounting connection, is from the top not the bottom of the back of the unit. The difference in design does matter, angles that the unit can cover are different, you can't tip it down as much. If you don't have to tip it down for your best angle then you're ok, but it won't work in the location I bought this to cover.UPDATE: OK, So after several emails with Ring, telling me I'd bought the wrong one (which I didn't) it turns out after you open the bottom end, with the sensor, you can slip off the case from the main body of the unit and turn it around so the mounting connection is how it is advertised as looking. Review Text: Camera works as expected. Video/audio is good. Coverage area and lighting is good.  Super easy to install and set up.  Camera comes with one lithium ion battery, but has two compartments if you choose to buy another battery.  So far I have 240 “events” with one battery installed (7 events per day average), and the battery is at 50% charge.  It’s been installed for 5 weeks.  I have this particular camera installed on my back patio. The good thing is that I can turn it on and off via the app on my phone or tablet.  Lights on the camera will easily illuminate a 15 X 15 area, if not moreRemember these cameras work via Wi-Fi.  99% of your problems, if any, are going to be router related.  If any of your Ring devices are located farther than 15/20 feet from your router you may  have issues. Tip - Get yourself a really good router.  I purchased a Netgear Nighthawk from Amazon. Forget the Chime Pro Wi-Fi extender that Ring sells. It won’t solve your problems.  Delay receiving alerts, video/audio quality, video lag, etc. are all going to be the problem of weak router.

The wide camera angle provides a great, wide coverage area.I also installed the Windows Ring app, which alerts me on my computer, which is convenient. It allows for virtually all the same functionality of the app.I have ended up getting 2 more cameras and solar panels to cover other areas of my property. Why there's a windows app, I have no idea. Regardless. Brand new camera, great wireless signal and speeds, all functions seem to work in the app except for the live feed. Not good when the product is a "camera". Anyways, the Ring app shows a black screen on both my phone and PC, and the app crashes in about 20 seconds after opening, every time. So it's pretty much worthless. I stumped customer service, they have no fix. I have no programs installed that are on their incompatibility list. I guess this thing is just not made for me. Best of luck out there! Looks like i'll be getting an Arlo or Nest. Will do some research. This product has a lot of R&D to do. Too bad, sounded great. Oh yea, 15 minute hold on customer service. Almost long enough for me to give up the call, but I hung on. Still, they were unhelpful with this issue. Review Title: A novelty item not a security system...
Review Text:
The media could not be loaded.
                




   I believed the commercials and purchased 4 ring products (3 spotlight cams Battery "HD" and 1 wired camera). That was quite an investment and I have had lots of trouble with them.The way I expected it to work (the way the commercial shows it working) is that the ring camera alerts you on your phone, you push a button and see what triggered the alarm (motion). However the reality is that about 60% of the time the cameras either don't display on the app / phone or they take so long that whatever triggered it has done what it wanted to do and is long gone (sometimes its 3 or 4 minutes). Ring help asks lots of questions about my wi-fi, however I have 180 Mbps and the ring camera I have the most trouble with is no more than 20 feet from my router, and my TV that streams 4K movies without interruption is 10 feet from my ring camera. My wi-fi is not the problem, their device is. There is also the issue of "your battery is below 50% this may take a moment longer" when you are trying to see what has triggered your camera, and only one of your batteries is below 50% the other one (in the same camera) is at full charge.Finally,  if and when you do get an image many times if there is motion in the image, the image pixilates so badly (the motion confuses it?) that you only see a blur and have no idea who it is or what they are doing. I will not mention the freezing of the video as well at times. Also I put "HD" in quotes because its nothing like high def. If a person is 25 feet away from the camera you can hardly tell their gender let alone who they are or what they look like.This is a novelty item only, don't rely on it for security. Its nice to be at work and see if a delivery is being dropped off at  your house from time to time. but if it only works  40% of the time, and many times takes forever to load an image... I don't call that security. It needs to be more like 99% reliable for me to think of this as a "home security system". I'm very sorry I spent the money I did on this product and would want to warn off anyone else looking into this system: it’s very expensive and very unreliable. With so many other systems on the market I would now look into other products that are more robust with better cameras and microphones ( another area that Ring disappoints is audio, obviously Avery cheap microphone in this very expensive product).Update: Ive has this system for almost a year and have no faith in it. It almost never works. I’m actually surprised when it does. It’s not my wi-fi which is excellent. It’s their cameras. I literally only rely on it for package delivery notice which works about 50% of the time. I had added a video of the typical response you get from an alarm ... which apparently was removed, the upshot of the video is: the little circle spins for 1:05 and then quits... you never get an image.
