Review Title: Buyers beware. PLEASE READ before purchasing.
Review Text: I REALLY wanted to like this video camera. But after 2 days of toiling with connectivity and unresponsiveness, I've decided to throw in the towel.I have a coworker who has owned the Ring doorbell camera for over a year now. He loves it. I've see the sensitivity of the motion sensor coupled with the picture quality. After a year of deliberating whether or not to make the purchase, I went for it.My front door is situated very precariously. The front of the house faces north. This includes the front door. However, the wall my existing doorbell is on faces west, directly to the left of the front door. The exterior wall for the garage space extends slightly farther than the front door does. I didn't build the house. I would have placed the doorbell to the right of the front door facing the same direction as everything else. But it is what it is.However, for the aforementioned reasons, I didn't buy the doorbell camera. I would have been very limited as far as motion detection and the cameras field of view were concerned. So after researching related products, I gravitated towards the Spotlight Camera with the Battery. It was wireless, and it was advertised the battery would last 6-12 months. First of all, let me say this is BULL CRAP! You will NEVER get 6 months out of that battery on a single charge. NEVER! After playing with the camera for 1 day trying to dial it in, I was down to 80% battery. That was in 1 day from a 100% charge. Granted I was using the camera more than the average person would use it in a single day, but nonetheless, their claim that this will last for 6-12 months on a single charge is FLAT OUT false advertisement.The camera has a slot for a 2nd battery. I ordered one BEFORE I discovered how much I loathed this device. I called Ring today to cancel my order. The gentleman on the phone told me that the order had been processed, but hadn't been shipped yet. He told me he can't stop the process now, but he would note my account so when I returned the item they would credit me back the money. Now I'll admit that $30 doesn't break the bank, but it just seems really odd to me that he couldn't stop the transaction and refund me my money..... But..... back to why I hate this device.So knowing my visual limitations with the position of the doorbell, I chose a nice location to the right of my door under the eve. It was located about 10' up. I have Cox broadband at my house and my average internet speed is 60 Mbps. But since my wireless router is on the opposing side of the house and on the 2nd floor, I installed a wireless range extender in the outlet closest to the wall/corner that I was hanging the camera. I knew for a long time before the purchase that I was going to be placing the camera where I had, so the range extended was installed months ago. I've had multiple devices linked up to it over those months to maintain/verify it's reliability. Through the extender I've averaged 25 Mbps down, and 6 Mbps up. It's never dropped out, and it's never fallen below those speeds. I guess what I'm trying to say is it's solid as a rock!So the set up for the ring is easy. The booklet coupled with the App walk you through the entire process. Even the technically challenged person can set this up. These are things that are very important to note that weren't explained to me during the set up, or in the instructions. You can invite several "guests" to "share" the network, but they don't have the same privilege level as the owner. This wasn't a deal breaker for me, but it wasn't something I knew until after purchasing the product. So the person "sharing" the network cannot erase events or tweak some features on the camera. Not too big of a deal.The sensitivity and features of this camera seem to have a mind of their own. Regarding the functionality, it works 15-20% of the time. I'm not kidding, and I'm not embellishing- 15-20% of the time. I will get notifications saying there is motion at the front of my house, and I will play back the 30 minute recording to discover a black screen with the pretty little ring logo in the left corner. No picture whatsoever. I've also gotten recordings where the frame is frozen on a still image, but the audio comes through. And don't even get me started on the "Live View" function of this camera. That might perhaps be one of the most technically frustrating features I've ever dealt with. It will work for you 1 out of ever 5 or 6 attempts. It will say "Live View", and make it seem like it's starting (as the camera backdrop never changes) with a fuzzy image of what your would expect to see. You can just make out that it's the backdrop you're used to seeing from the fixed view of the camera. Then you get that stupid buffering wheel that just hangs, and hangs, and hangs there until you finally get so frustrated you back out of the feature. Then you'll try it again. And the result will be different. Maybe you'll get to the live view, but you more than likely will get less further along than the first attempt.The picture is grainy! It's supposed to be 1080. Well, if the person was within 3 feet of the camera, the picture would be beautiful. But from 15' away it's just ok. You could make out details (clothes, colors, gender, race, animals, etc....), but not with absolute precision and accuracy like what I would expect from a true 1080 picture. And trust me..... I know picture quality. I work in Broadcast Video for a huge telecom company and I work with TRUE uncompressed, high definition broadcast video equipment. That being said, I'm also no slouch when it comes to my intellect. Admittedly I'm not the smartest guy in the world, but I can say with a measure of confidence I'm above the average. I KNOW I'm doing everything right on my end.Last night I experimented with the camera before and after sunset. Sometimes I could set the camera off with my motion, and sometimes I could not. I tried every possible combination of wait times to see if the camera needed a "rest period" between recordings. It didn't matter. At one point I even climbed up onto a planter box that allows me to perch myself within 2' of the camera. It STILL failed to trigger a response. Like I said, it has a mind of it's own.But the most troubling thing of all happened to me this morning. We have a huge coyote population in my neighborhood. They love to walk across my yard and leave me"'presents" on my driveway and lawn- both of which are in the motion zone I set up for this camera. They are there EVERY NIGHT. So I expected to see motion activity on the camera when I got up this morning. But that isn't what I saw. I launched the app, then got a reply saying that there was an issue communicating with the camera. So I walked over to the range extender (remember- that is only 10' away from the camera on the inside of the wall) and discovered the link light for the device (the camera) was no longer green, but was amber, indicating no sync with any device. Apparently the ring camera decided to just drop off the network during the middle of the night, and not reconnect.So the reason I have this camera is because it's completely unreliable. It works when it wants to, but unfortunately that is less than 1/2 of the time. If you bought this camera, it was purchased as a means to safeguard your home and your family. You want it to work 100% of the time. And it SHOULD!So why do I think this is happening? Remember, I'm a tech guy. I deal with IP Ethernet, High Def Video, and packets of 1's and 0's all day long. I think the Ring company has bitten off more than they can chew. I believe their facilities that house their servers are inadequate to handle the traffic from the millions of Ring owners out there. The data hits a digital "bottleneck" and you get buffering. Servers can't be pressurized. You can't squeeze in more than what they're set up to handle. I also think that their data lines to communicate with the world are inadequate. Same concept as the servers. Too much traffic, too narrow a road. So it's my opinion that Ring really needs to step up their game and upgrade their layer 1 network.This morning I came and and shared my story with my coworkers- one of which was the gentleman that sold me on the Ring. He told me that he experiences the same issues I was talking about, specifically with the Live View. Then 2 other coworkers chimed in who are Ring owners. They also said they had issues. So there are 4 people in the room that own the Ring, and with 100% consistency we all experienced issues. This is a MAJOR PROBLEM!I'm returning the Ring and buying a competitive (slightly more expensive) camera system for my home. In my opinion, Ring is garbage! There are better options that are much more reliable. Remember why you're buying the system. You can't put a price on your family.

Review Title: Consider camera response time befor you buy this or any other system.
Review Text: This is not so much a review of this camera but more a review of the Ring system in general. I purchased four cameras for outdoor use and generally they work very well but there are some things you need to be aware of.A. Response time. The cameras are advertised for the doorbell feature that is supposed to pick up the face of somebody at your front door or somebody stealing your Amazon packages. Response time is so slow that it usually only gets the back of the head of a person unless they stand there very still for a few moments.B. Reliability – the cameras do not pick up every event that happens. If the camera has been triggered it may not go off again the next time somebody walks in front of it. Nighttime reliability is much worse. We have had people walk up to the front door, knock on the door, moved to the kitchen window and yelled to see if were home, and then walk away. None of that event was captured by the front door camera.C. Arizona heat – the camera mounted in our carport is underneath the carport but we are told by Ring that the Arizona heat is so bad that it causes the camera to trigger during the day. It does this every 60 seconds. Ring did an update on the software and it has gotten much better nowD. Action notice response – on more than one occasion somebody has come up to the house and triggered an action notice on my cell phone. Occasionally I get the notice and before I can actually open it in time to talk to these people and do something about the event the people triggering the system have gone.  I do need to point out however that if you actually are able to see the people in the “live” mode the system works extremely well in allowing you to speak to them and hear them and it has a profound effect on people standing in front of your door.E. Overall based on the cost, the availability of solar power for the cameras, and ease-of-use I decided not to send this back. I just know that sometimes the system is not going to record events I really probably would like to know. Prior to this I had installed Arlo systems in the same locations I now have Ring devices. Arlo has the same response and reliability problems that Ring does and it does not come with the solar power option.So in the end if you need a highly reliable, wireless system you need to spend a lot more money on much higher quality components.

Review Text: Good security device, especially if you already have other Ring devices and/or Amazon Alexa, but has some downfall. There are random cuts in video where the screen freezes and doesn't record again until the motion stopped, and sometimes even a total black screen. The video is often grainy, especially at night. Review Title: Useless When Placed in Rain Proned Areas.
Review Text: I've owned 3 of these, hoping for improvement from the first one I bought when they first came out. I've also had 3 replacements sent out for the 3 I've owned, all within the warranty period. When they get wet from a good soaking rain they will fail. You'll get an error that says battery door open, then within a day, it's shot and will cease functioning completely.I called ring today, and told them it's an inferior design issue. I was told by a wonderful csr person that they are not waterproof, they're only water resistant. That they need to be set up under like an awning or some coverage. I said it kinda defeats the purpose of using it when you can only put it where there is an awning or something. She agreed, but she said that's why they are only marketed as water resistant and care needs to be exercised when placing the unit. I then said, that once again totally defeats the purpose of the camera if it can only be placed in an area that doesn't get wet. She agreed again. She said the only thing she can do is replace the unit free of charge,which I agreed to.Moral of the story, if you can't place this unit under cover, it'll become useless as soon as it gets a good rain. My advice is to stay away from it and find another alternative. Or you can do as I have done 3 times so far. Call and have a replacement sent out and deal with it that way. Buyer beware!!!

Review Title: Beyond simply quirky!  Useless is more appropriate!
Review Text: Dislikes? Pretty much everything about this overhyped product! Asking what it is used for in the review is symptomatic of what is wrong about this product. It's a SECURITY camera! It wasn't purchased to video record weddings and family gatherings! Another point is the suggestion to initially install it ”near” the router! Excuse me? The camera HAS to be installed where it is NEEDED! A further suggestion to move the camera or relocate ones router if there are issues is simply beyond ridiculous. The router is initially placed by the installation technician and while not ”writ in stone” it's placement is guided by the locations of other devices on my homes entire network. It's not as I live on an extensive estate. My home is a double wide mobile home. Purchasing the Chime Pro only succeeded in Amazon getting more of my money!I purchased the one device with the intent of purchasing another to handle the other side of my property. That now is absolutely out of the question. I'll keep the one but never get another! I DO NOT recommend this to anyone who sees Ring’s TV ads and thinks it's a worthwhile home security option.Siren? A pathetic meow that a baby kitten puts to shame. Two way communication is almost as bad. Testing with my wife as the intruder was a joke. Neither of us could hear the other! Motion detection is triggered by butterflies! Motion zone setting is with one device exception (iPhone) impossible to tailor to your specific setup. I've RING installed on an iPad, a Fire HD 10, a Galaxy S9 and an iPhone 6S Plus. All other devices have a meaningless graphical representation. IPad Version doesn't have a ”save” button In establishing motion zones making using the iPad worthless .As motion is ”detected” and a video record made I’ll keep the device as it at least will provide video evidence of my losses for a police report, it not being of any use whatsoever in actual loss prevention! The lag time between event trigger and notification is so long as to be of no value. By the time you are notified intruders (thieves) are long since gone.Caveat emptor! At least this product has provided me with a reason to actually use the term ”caveat emptor” in a real world setting! Caveat emptor!Hilarious that the Ring app isn't even available for Amazon's own Fire HD 10!  Neighbors yes, the Ring app for the Ring device itself, no!  Really pathetic!  The inventor made out like a bandit selling out to Amazon.

Review Text: I’ve spent about $800 on a few of the ring products, and I’ll never purchase an item from them again. Customer service is horrible. When faced with a fault product, you’ve got to spend an hour on the phone and fight to get a replacement. You’re best off to buy cameras that are wired.Any WiFi security cam is never going to produce the result of clarity as ones that you’ve got to run a cable. Also, wired cams are WAYYYYY CHEAPER, and you don’t have to pay for a service to review recorded footage. Majority of the wired cams also allow all the mobile software features such as alerts and notification. Now, my review on the quality.Product quality is absolute trash on this camera, and I’d never recommend this spotlight cam for many reasons. For one, the light is absolutely worthless on this camera. When the light kicks on from any motion, you cannot see anything!! There’s also no feature to disable the light. Secondly, this product —like majority of the ring cameras—is garbage. You cannot see anything clearly past 10ft and the night vision is horrible.Lastly, connection... all of the 4 ring products I have are plagued with connection issues, and this is not due to my internet speed. Trust me, I’ve got several products on WiFi that never encounter near the peak of problems that this camera’s have. You get kicked offline when viewing with random software app crashes, and half the time, you cannot connect to view live footage at all....Btw, if you play on mounting this product anywhere by the roof, be prepared to drill a 2” hole in your house (thank god I didn’t). Otherwise, the only option to plug this cam in is by exterior or extension cord—leaving the cable prone to be damaged by any future thieves.Since then, I’ve removed all of these spotlight cams. I’m not going to leave a bias product referral to another product, but I can tell you for the price you pay for two of these cams, you can get double your money’s worth with better quality products—better night vision, image, and distance zooming features—without paying monthly fees.  Running cables might seem like a headache, but it’s much more of headache using these cameras. Stick with cable. If you cannot do it, pay someone.Only feasible products from ring are the doorbell, and somewhat the spotlight. Even then, I’m about to replace those two.

Review Text: Another update - The real-time use of the phone app and the Ring camera's is still spotty. Last night the mic didn't connect for 20 seconds, but the day before it connected right away.  I think some notifications showing the status of the connection process on the phone would be helpful. Otherwise you just sit and wait. But the app I noticed no longer times out, which is a HUGE improvement. We had to uninstall the phone app and install it again and this seemed to help. But the technology still needs work. I am improving the rating by one star. C'mon Ring, I know you can do it. You can get this app and the cameras to work 99% flawlessly.----------------------------------------------------------------I am updating this review because I just got off the phone with Ring and get excellent customer support. They are eager to resolve the issue. However, when they called, my system was working without ANY issue. Isn't that typical. We are going to keep an eye on things this weekend and when we have issues we will email our designated tech rep. Very cool. I do plan on sticking with our system because I believe they will work this out, and the system will only get better. We will see how things go, and I will adjust my rating accordingly.------------------------------------------------------------------We have spent about $800 on a Ring system from our home 3 cameras and a doorbell. Installation was easy and we were pretty excited to see it in action, and that is where this system absolutely bomb, to put it politely. I can't tell you how many times I have tried to respond to a camera picking up movement and I am unable to access the camera. I have submitted several reports to Ring so hopefully they are working on the system. When I do access the camera, it take soooooo long, including the doorbell, that whomever rang the bell would be gone by the time it comes up on my phone. I use the windows in my house to see who it is because it is faster. They should sell free window installments with the system.When I do connect, seriously after about 20 seconds minimum, none of the buttons on the phone app respond, and if they do it takes another 20 seconds. Any thief could steal the foundation to my home by the time I can yell, "Get out of my yard". About 50% of the time the phone app crashes, either before connecting or after connecting to the camera.I am not sure any other system would work better, so not willing to give another company a shot. I really think if they get this connectivity fixed it would be a great system.Here are some other facts: The Ring system is designed to work with the 2.4Ghz wireless connection because of the extended range, but my house is small, so I would like to try the 5Ghz range. But I cant! I have a new Nighthawk router/modem, top of the line. I have a Samsung J7 about 1 year old at most.I do not believe technology is the issue here. I really wish they would figure out the issues and fix the problems fast, because I do not really see how this system helps me in real-time response. I am keeping the system because I know it scares people off, and I can access the history of events, plus they have a cool community site to see what is going on in your community.Once Ring fixes the real-time connectivity to the cameras I will be glad to change this rating.Really frustrated and disappointed.

Review Title: Bad battery life, wifi and inconsistent live view
Review Text: Bad wifi capabilities. Even with speed tests of 50 Mbps up and 48 Mbps down with 0% packet loss at camera location, it still says there is poor wifi and very inconsistent connections (especially live view which regularly results in black screen).A big issue is the statements about battery life. With only 3-4 motion events captured the battery drains about 10% in a day. There's no way I'll get even one month of life from this unless it never goes off. Will be a pain to keep things charged.For reference my neighbor uses a different brand and his batteries lasted 6+ months no problems with pretty regular captures throughout the day.Update:After having it up for a little while now, also noticed it is really prone to false alarms. Since standard setting only picks up stuff very X minutes, means things can get missed. The smallest breeze causes it to fire off, guessing because there's bushes at front of house that sway around. This means I have to reduce motion zone which makes it useless.They need to do a better job differentiating real events versus breezes. At the same time it completely missed the wife and I walking right through our front door and the camera was pointed right at it not that far aware. Very very inconsistent.Update 2:Ring app is also bad. Crashes regularly. Today I've been unable to connect to it now for an hour because it "can't reach cloud servers".

Review Title: An all around good camera system.
Review Text: I have been back and forth in getting cameras for our home for a while. We had family get someof the ring system and was impressed by the quality. When we moved to our new house, we had some of our kids toys stolen from the front yard the first day we were here and that made the decision to get a system.I was between Ring and Blink. When comparing several videos and taking into account not just image quality but the larger field of view with ring, that pushed me toward ring. When I saw that ring had a stolen camera replacement policy (I mean, it’s not that hard to pop the spotlight cam out of the mount if you really want it) that cinched the deal.Installation was easier than I expected, but both of my ring spotlight cameras went into wood. Each has a mount with a ball in socket connection that is tightened with an included torx type bit while the mounting screws (4 for each camera) are Phillips (also included bit).The spotlight camera has capacity for two batteries, and comes with one battery. My family with a ring system recommended to fill both bays so I bought an extra battery for each camera so when the battery dies, the camera can run off the spare while the primary charges (approximately 10-12 hour charge time on a 1 A charge).They do push the ring subscription but is not required. I went ahead and bit since it was $100 for the whole year and it extends your warranty as long as you have the subscription.Setup in the Ring app was simple. Start it up and follow the prompts. It wasn’t an issue for us, but when planning hour camera placement, make sure your WiFi strength is stout wherever you want to place them.They do tend to have a little bit of a “boy who cried wolf” feel with how many alerts I get but I know I’m still in the trial and error part of setting the sensitivity and don’t hold this against the system. I do with the battery version let you trace out the tracking area like the hard wired versions.Overall, it’s a good system that is relatively simple to set up with good video quality, field of view, and relatively affordable premium subscription level.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2019

Review Title: Try to find one at a discount
Review Text: This is a nice camera with plenty of features -- lights, speakers, and a plethora of motion detection and recording options.  Battery life is quite good.  I have mine pointing towards the front of my house with a custom zone to avoid sidewalk traffic and the battery lasts about a month.  I don't mind charging it every few weeks.  However, it seems overpriced at $200.  This is a great camera that can be mounted anywhere within a wifi access point, but $200 for a single camera is steep.  Amazon runs sales where you can get the camera around $150 which seems like a reasonable price for what you get.  You may be able to get a decent used or refurbished one for even less.  I would wait for those opportunities and not pay full price.One tip for those not receiving motion notifications.  Try disabling any battery optimization for the Ring app.  I have a OnePlus 6t and wasn't receiving alerts consistently.  But then, after disabling the battery optimization, alerts came in for all detected motion.

Review Title: Great camera. Get the solar panel and raise your router
Review Text: I received the Ring Spotlight Camera for Christmas this year, to complement the Ring doorbell Pro I put in last year  and like very much. I wasn't even sure I wanted the video doorbell at first but it's so handy and satisfying to be able to keep track of what's going on around the house that it seems like a no-brainer now.  This Ring cam is every bit as good --  a well-constructed device that's easy to install, comes with good, clear instructions , a solid mount, and a powerful app backing it up.My installationI put the camera under the eaves, near the center of the garage door to capture the driveway, mailbox, and a good chunk of the front yard. Ring recommends keeping it out of direct rain and frankly that just seems like the smart way to go whenever you can.  The lens angle is a super-wide, "fisheye" type and captures a broad area. I installed the Ring solar panel because I didn't want to worry about battery life. The mount is easy to deal with (just a couple of screws, included) and is very secure once you tighten down a collar holding the ball coming off the camera into the socket on the mount. The solar panel is mounted on the outside trim of the roof because unlike the camera, it needs full exposure. It's oriented east (South is best for solar panels in this hemisphere) but keeps the battery at 100%.ProsConstructionBuild quality is strong. This is a heavy piece for its size. The lens is of a good size and the case is solid. I dropped it once during installation from several feet above a concrete driveway, and it came away with just a small scuff. All the packing materials, cords, etc. have a heavy-duty, premium feel to them.Image qualityThe view from the camera is clear and sharp with bright, saturated colors in good light. It doesn't have tremendous resolution at distance (I don't think you could identify a face at the mailbox 40 feet away, for example) but it looks good. Nightvision is black and white unless the light comes on, but is also of good clarity for a modern security camera. I have a separate motion detector light mounted nearby that helps it "see" in color as well (not a security nut; just had the other light there first).Motion DetectionWorks well, but motion detection is tricky to tune if you have a street-facing camera and don't want 10 million notifications. Ring has some tweaks for turning it "down" and modifying the areas it monitors, but having lost two mailboxes to careless drivers, I want to see the street. I just let it record every car that goes by , but we live on a quiet cul-de-sac. You may want to "de-tune" motion detection more if your camera faces a busy street.RecordingSpeaking of which, Ring does make you pay if you want to keep recordings of  motion-detected "events." $30/yr per device, or $100 for unlimited devices. I'm paying the $60 for two devices and I'm okay with that. If you ever actually need a security camera for ... security ... you'll want a record. You can scan through the recorded events to see what's going on generally, or just ignore them. I do like to check as to anyone passing by the house between say, midnight and 5 a.m., and the timestamps allow checking just those (nothing of note so far besides the landscaping guy down the street starting his day in the middle of the night and the neighbor's kid cutting through the yard for whatever high schoolers are doing at 4 a.m. these days).The Ring appI'm sure people have legitimate gripes about the app (because, apps) but overall it's powerful and user friendly.  Linking my doorbell cam, the garage/front yard cam, and a few Ring pathlights makes for a convenient way to check everything going on around the house. Ring gives live updates when there's any kind of known issue. The "device health" and wifi testing features have been helpful in getting my setup dialed in correctly. The "Neighbors" feature, which has received some criticism for potential abuse by law enforcement  (they still need permission to view your footage) is  actually good to have in my opinion.  People post footage from any local shenanigans, which you can track by location, and the occasional lost/found dog. It has also been educational seeing what some people find alarming, such as a teenager with a clipboard coming to the door in the middle of the day.The light is good for the immediate areaIt's plenty bright, but doesn't have a lot of "throw" over distance (despite the name, this is not the model with the big spotlights on it). It's enough to light up the area directly in front of it in the driveway. Good enough to let someone know there's a camera present and to see your way around a few yards.Ring Solar Panel compatibilityThis is not a review of the solar panel, but being able to keep the battery charged indefinitely is a huge plus. Simple to install; looks and works greatConsYour wifi mileage may vary, and sometimes going to the "live" feed  takes a long time, so much so that Ring has a whole separate app that's supposed to allow you faster access. That tells me it may be something in Ring's system that slows delivery. However, the app leads you through tips to speed things up, and what finally worked for me was raising my wifi router up about 2 inches by setting it on a book. I wish the mount allowed the camera to angle a bit more, particularly up and down. I wish recordings were free and the devices were less expensive, and a new update puts a "siren" button a little prominently on the the home page (not something you want to hit inadvertently) but overall this camera does what I wanted: I can see what's going on around the outside of the house at all times, from anywhere. Obviously nice for security, but it's even handy to meet someone coming to the door before the dogs go bananas.Tips:1. Get the solar panel, and make sure the single battery (it's all you need with the panel)  is installed in the left slot (the app will tell you which slot holds the battery to clarify) As near as I can tell, that's the only one that receives solar charging. Half a day in the "right" slot got zero charge, whereas it charged up to 100% from 60 or so in just a couple of hours with the battery on the left.2. If you're having connectivity issues, first try just raising the physical height of your wifi router before worrying about fancy fixes like a wifi extender. It may sound silly, but nothing, including moving the Ring hub all over the place, helped like raising my router two inches by putting it on a book. High tech camera, meet the power of the printing press.3. Multiple devices combined with the app really make this system shine. Open the app and see what's going on with the front porch from the doorbell cam, and whatever exterior views you have covered otherwise.  Check to see where your dogs are by way of the motion-sensing pathlights. The Ring system makes it  simple to combine your views and link the products together.Five stars.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2020

Review Text: After nearly two years of owning this camera, we're ready to throw in the towel. The whole point of a security camera is that it's supposed to work on those rare instances when you need it to. It's very hard to get the motion sensitivity to the right level and it goes off constantly at the slightest movement, even after tweaking the zones to practically two feet away from the camera, which is of course useless from a security point of view.The worst is accessing Live View: it's maddeningly inconsistent and frustratingly out-of-order precisely when you need it most (i.e. when motion has been detected and you're trying to see what's up: who's at your door or on your property). The error message "Having trouble accessing Live View" is all too common, and if you try to click "More Info" you're directed to a useless support page that shows nothing about how to address or troubleshoot the problem. It's definitely not our wifi or battery life (we have the solar battery panel too) or connectivity issues on our end, as sometimes it works fine but more often than not it doesn't. Calling customer service is a joke and wastes endless time, with no resolution—probably because the simple plain fact is that this product just doesn't work well. This camera is not worth the money or trouble, nor does it reliably perform the functions a security camera should. Look elsewhere.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021

Review Text: July 2020 updated review:A few months ago, I noticed ring updated their software so there wouldn’t be so much of a lapse in time between videos when there is still motion in the zone. One video ends, and the next video picks up almost right away. I’m now very happy with my camera!June 2019 review:I bought two of these spotlight cameras in November from Home Depot, so that’s why this isn’t a verified purchase review....wanted to preface with that.These are “okay” cameras. Can't wait for Wyze to release their outdoor and doorbell cameras. I have 6 of the originals, including some outside, and they have literally never failed, and they're under 50 bucks. Lasted 4 HOURS before dying. Batteries are still full. What a joke. My $25 Wyze camera has been working flawlessly outdoors in a protective case for awhile, yet this $200 lemon won't? WTH?Update: 05/28/19A couple weeks ago, after my review, Alexis from Ring reached out and said they were willing to send me either a replacement spotlight cam solar or stick up cam solar. If you want cameras just to record videos for later, this is perfect, but I get motion alerts and it takes so damn long to load live view whatever caused the motion is long gone. Someone will ring the bell and it takes so long to open live stream they've either left or it's just easier to go to the door and look through the peephole. For the money, they don't work that well.And it's not the wifi. We have an Orbi mesh system and get over 600 mbps

Review Title: Not reliable and frustrating software for everyday functions
Review Text: I purchased a ring door bell and two stick up cams, (plug in) Everything installed fine and the software is easy enough to get everything set up on your smarter devices. But then when it comes to actual function, I became very dissatisfied. The ring door bell works good. It was the most reliable item. I’m happy with that. When I set it up with our Alexa, I was happy how it worked with the door bell and motion alerts. It made me go ahead and purchase the two stick up cams. They were the start of nightmares. They false a lot. When there is motion, the motion is usually gone before the video had started recording, and I only get to see that 50% of the time, as the other times the little icon just spins until it comes up telling me to retry to connect. It kept showing me weak signal. I have a large house, but a pretty new router. We have no issues with our smart devices. I did have an older extender, so I replaced it with a very nice Netgear extender. Our WiFi was now great with our smart devices on streaming, but saw no change in the cameras. I then purchased the chime pro so the door bell could be heard easily and see if that would help with the signal. Nope, the device manager in the software shows weak signals on one camera from one day to another. The reaction time doesn’t seem to improve or worsen when it says it has a weak signal or good signal. I wanted to be able to hear the doorbell out on our patio, so I purchased another pro chime and was hoping it would help the backyard camera. No luck on the reaction time, but I do always show a good signal now. But that created another issue, I now get two alerts every time there is motion. They are back to back alerts, and I get them 12-15 times a day when it is windy. That brings me to another sore subject. The alerts. I cannot believe Ring made such poor software to manage the devices. When it is windy and I want to turn the motion alerts off for that camera, I then found out that the alerts only turn off on the device you turn it off on. Not the camera itself. So I can turn my phone off, but my wife still gets them and both of our alexa’s. On windy days, it is quit annoying. I have to actual turn the voice off on the alexa’s to stop those. I’m sorry, but I think that is pretty simple functions to add to software. I have checked my devices on the app and there is nothing showing me it should be sending double alerts. It started when I added the chime pro on the back patio, but I have that device set to do nothing on any alerts on motion. Don’t know what else I can do. Another annoying problem I have just started experiencing. I have had the system installed for over a month now and the free 30 day trial has run out. So if the motion alerts do not load immediately and I get the reconnect message, it then tells me I have no saved video when it does connect because I haven’t purchased that plan. It’s funny how that this problem has increased since the 30 day trial ran out. I had planned on purchasing at least the $3.00 a month plan, but I feel I have invested enough into Ring to keep going.The Ring company has proven they are not putting in the effort to make this the greatest product of this type. I read the community blog, and its one thing after another like I have dealt with. I had thought about increasing my home security to the Ring security system, but no chance now. There is just way too much lack of reliability. I feel I have give this product a fair shot and time. It’s not a great amount of money, but I have invested money and time on several ring products. It has been over a month now since I installed it.I have put a lot of time into trying to work the bugs out and make sure it wasn’t operator error. A lot of reading in the Community blog. That just frustrates me more. I do not recommend the cameras from Ring. My next plan is to see what security cameras and software work with Alexa. I like that feature, I just want to be able to control the alerts from the cameras themselves so all the devices are getting the same adjustments.

Review Title: Loading, Can't Connect, Dead Battery, Incomplete clips
Review Text: I don't love this product. It "gets the job done", so to speak, but it is really lacking in a lot of areas -1. I use the battery-powered version and I live on a city street where people are walking past a decent amount. So it's probably triggered on about 20-30 times a day. The battery lasts about a week. I had to buy a backup battery and now it still only lasts about 2-3 weeks and the batteries take about a day to charge. They also aren't super cheap.2. The clips are so short. They only run for like 15-20 seconds and I checked all of the settings. So if someone is messing around outside of your house, you won't get continuous footage. I get why this kinda makes sense, but it's frustrating nonetheless. Maybe an alert to say "we've been recording for 2 minutes, want us to stop?" would make sense.3. Connecting to my camera live is a nightmare. If someone is knocking at the door and my dog is barking, I'll try to get a live view to see who it is. The app takes at least 20-30 seconds to connect to the live view and even then sometimes it says connection failed. So I'll have to exit the app and open it up again and restart the load. By then, my estranged family members have already broken into my house.4. As a front door view, this angle isn't the best. I know that's my fault and I could have bought a standard doorbell, but just a heads up that this doesn't work best for above the front door because you can't see faces.5. The motion detection sucks. I know there's intentional pauses between motion to preserve battery life. Even with taking them off, it always misses the one thing I'm looking for or cuts off too soon.6. The storage system. So it's cool that you can get unlimited storage...but it costs $3 a month. Which isn't so bad, but it increases to $10 a month if you have multiple cameras. That's a lot. I don't need my clips stored indefinitely. How about an option for just a month retention rate that is cheaper?Pros - the quality of the image is stellar. The sound comes through good.

Review Title: Overall good but let down by a couple of quirks.
Review Text: Only having a 5 star system here, I can only really give it 3 stars, though I'd up it to 3 1/2 if that were possible - it's solid, but does have a couple of quirks.  The first being that the motion sensitivity adjustment is VERY off based on the screen it shows you when you are adjusting it.  I have a long (30 ft) driveway.  When I first adjusted the motion sensitivity, I excluded the street area as I did not want an alert every time a car went up the street, but, regardless of the setting, I still got one.  Every... single... car.  So, I pulled it back a bit.  Same result.  More - same.  According to the adjustment screen, I have pulled sensitivity back HALFWAY down my driveway now, and I still will get an alert when a car drives past my house (often).  This will of course, greatly shorten battery life.The other quirt is WiFi antennae strength.  It's not as strong as some other similar devices I've tried.  It's stronger than their doorbell cams, but not as much as other branded battery cameras I've tried.The video quality is ok - not quite "clear 1080p" ok, but still better than average.  The lights are not super bright but give off enough given what the device is.  The app is easy enough to maneuver around.  But due to the very ineffective motion sensing controls, I'd have to say this would be good more for back yard/door observations, side yards, etc. rather than a front driveway if you have a decent amount of traffic that's going to pass by all day.  They need to work on that - if the mapping diagram shows it will only pick up motion to point "A" but it extends to point "B" no matter what you do, it becomes so irritating you're tempted the turn it off - and then what's the point of having it?

Review Text: I was initially going to go with a cheaper camera that had good reviews, but after comparing specs in a brick and mortar store, I decided to pony up the extra cash for the Ring Spotlight Battery, mostly for the two-way audio and solar charging option. Set up was easy enough. I got the app installed and connected the Ring to my WiFi, tested everything and then picked a spot and did the quick physical installation. The camera worked fine from about 1:30 p.m. to 6:15 p.m. I got notifications from some people walking up the street in front of my house and a few cars going by, which is fine for me.There were a few small flaws that bugged me initially. First, the battery compartment latch feels cheep and you really have to make sure you have it closed. Then around 4:30 I got a video where a guy on a dirt bike appeared to just freeze in the middle of the street for a few seconds before vanishing. Unless my neighbor has magical powers, the recording clearly had a gap in it even though the timer kept running.I left my house at 5:45, and the camera kept working for about half an hour. I got three more notifications during that time, but then I didn't get anything else. When I got home at 7, I didn't get a notification when I drove in front of my house. I tried walking in front of the camera. Nothing happened. I tried turning the light on and activating live view through the app. Neither worked, and it said there was a failure to connect to the camera.I went through the troubleshooting suggestions, but my app continued telling me my camera was online even when my router was resetting and it couldn't have been online. I tried pushing the button on the top of the camera as suggested and then pushed it again after 10 seconds. That didn't work either. I finally had to take the camera down and remove the battery. Remarkably, even with the battery out of the camera, the app still said the camera was online.After putting the battery back in, it looked like it still wasn't going to work, but about a minute later the lights suddenly came on and the app finally connected again. I put it back up, and it's been working since then. The app is showing it receives a strong WiFi signal, and the battery is still almost fully charged, so I don't think either of those were factors. I didn't have any sleep mode or motion detection rules set either.While the video quality is good and I like the interface of the app, I'm going to have a hard time justifying the price I paid for a security camera that is already having reliability issues in the first few hours of use. I'm going to keep it for a couple more days to see if the problems persist. I can get a Blink XT2 set with 3 cameras for the price I paid for 1 Ring with a solar charger.

Review Text: I have other Ring products that work fine however I do not recommend the spotlight cam, particularly the battery version. First, the light will trigger for events that happen outside the configured motion zone. However when checking the app there is no motion event. This means that if your camera is anywhere near a street passing cars will cause the light to trigger on and off continuously. No amount of tweaking the motion zones change the light problem. Review Text: I bought these off of Newegg.  Honestly, don't think I'd recommend them.  A few concerns:Pros:- Easy to set up, requiring no electrical set up and very simple to install especially if you have a power drill.Cons:- Battery life:  They say 6 month battery.  After only 3 days, I'm already at 66% battery life (fully charged before installing)- Motion detection:  It only detects motion in the bottom half of the screen, and doesn't consistently do so.  All morning, I've been notified every time birds have flown past the camera. BUT there has been a worker doing some window installation in the back that hasn't set off the motion alert one time.- Live view:  Quite glitchy.  It often takes a long time to load, and sometimes doesn't load at all.  If someone were to be stealing a package off of my porch, I think they'd be long gone before I even have a chance to open the app, load the live view, and set off the siren.I spent hours with two separate associates from Ring over the phone who at the end basically shrugged their shoulders and said these are just limitations with the device.EDIT: Ring contacted me to help fix the problem.  Ultimately, this does not change my review - they were not able to improve the performance of the products, and noted that these battery power devices are fundamentally different than the plug-in models of the same name, and have fewer sensitivity and motion-detecting options.  I did end up buying solar panels to power the devices (at my own cost), but ultimately,  I still would not re-purchase these cameras if I were starting again from scratch.

Review Title: The Good, the Bad & the Ugly UPDATED.....GOOD WITH A TEENY BIT OF BAD!
Review Text: UPDATE: RING Customer Service was VERY proactive in contacting me through email and phone. Alexis was wonderful in working diligently to solve the battery life problem. Now a 5 star review but going to leave initial review in place so if anyone has same issues they can see that a fix is possible.The Good: Ability to place anywhere on house or property without a power source being nearby is great. 2 way comms and the siren feature are invaluable. Installation and setup is fairly easy. The Ring app is better than most of its ilk.The Bad:  Motion sensors are TOO good. Takes great patience to set the zones up. blowing leaves, loud vehicles, etc. cause false alarms at an alarming rate! UPDATE...PLAY WITH SENSOR APP TO FINE TUNE.The Ugly: Battery life sucks. Even with 2 batteries installed, motion zones minimal, very few live look ins, lights off and alerts set to minimum I have been getting less than 30 days of service. SOLVED BY RING CUSTOMER SERVICE.The wifi issues? They are many. If wifi signal is bad, video is bad....makes sense. My internet is 300 mbs download AND upload. router 30 feet away. signal has to pass thru 1 plasterboard wall and outside wall with frame and vinyl siding. No metal or electronics between the 2. Test shows 10 out of 10 bars with 200mbs plus up & down speeds. Not good. At night video is blurry. Moved router to within 8 feet of Ring Spotcam.....better, but impractical. Used the Ring wifi extender (50 extra bucks). A little better but..... UPDATE. RETURNED RING EXTENDER AND BOUGHT A POWERLINE LAN/WIFI EXTENDER. USED SSID CLONE FUNCTION...RSSI WENT FROM -58 TO -44. VIDEO NOW PERFECT. FIGURING THE WAVE PROPAGATION OF THE EXTENDER BETTER THAN THE HTC ROUTER.Giving it a 3. Wifi and battery life is a concern but unit has it's good features too.

Review Text: I was going on vacation and after the easy installation of the Ring Door View Cam and a a chime, I thought I'd also install a Spotlight Camera on my back door.  Easier said than done.I bought a 2 pack from Best Buy, because I couldn't wait for an Amazon Prime delivery.  Got it when the store opened and went straight home to install it.  I already had a charged extra battery for the Door View Cam, so I was ready to go but despite my best efforts, the Spotlight Cam failed to set up properly after trying both cams..  I finally broke down and called Ring Customer service.  Was told to turn off my wireless printer and reset the router but the cam would still not set up.  Was told to try the other cam (which I had already tried before) and then all of a sudden the cam did in fact go thru the setup procedure and I have a live cam view from it and signed off w/Ring CS.But not so fast . . . LOL!I got a "low signal" notice because the cam was only operating on the 2.4Ghz band from my router and not the extender.  So, I stupidly tried to change the wi-fi network used and totally lost connection w/the Spotlight Cam.  Aghhh!!!Had to do some errands, so then I went out, did them and tried to reinstall the Spotlight cam on my return, which required me to "remove" the spotlight cam and attempt to reinstall it.  Took forever but it finally took but I'm NOT touching it again!!!A couple of things they don't tell you in the install process:1) When the Spotlight cam is trying to link w/your wireless network it will "create" a wireless called "Ring .  .  . Net access while the light in your Spotlight cam is "blinking."  Don't worry about the "no Net access."  The blinking means that the Spotlight cam is pairing w/your network and it needs to be left alone to complete the process.  I made the mistake of interrupting this process a couple of times, which is what made (to some degree) the installation problematic.  When it's done it will ask you which wi-fi connection the device should use and then take you thru a basic set up procedure, which you can change later.2)  If you have a stucco exterior on your house, like I do, the drill bit that comes w/the kit is worthless for drilling thru it.  I had to pull out my IMPACT DRILL and use a 4/64" (1/4") carbide impact drill bit (it comes w/a 5/16" non-carbide bit) in order to drill a hole thur the stucco so that I could mount the bracket for the Spotlight Cam on the exterior wall.Who else has an impact drill handy?  Not many people, I suspect.  So, if you'd got a stucco exterior, be warned!!3)  Lastly, the Spotlight Cam is supposed to include a siren (which is does) but none of the materials that came w/the cam indicated how that can be accessed/used.  I  called Ring CS again and they told me to bring up a live cam pic, which I did.  There is a + sign in the lower right hand corner of the live cam live.  Touch that icon and 3 additional icons come up: a) an exclamation point (that's the alarm), b) a light (that's the light) and c) a small pic w/3 heads, which is the link to "share" the video w/your neighbors.  In order to activate the alarm, just press the ! icon.I thought that it would only take an hour to install the  Spotlight Cam but w/the problems w/the software installation and with the physical installation of the bracket for the cam, it took closer to 4.  Again, be forewared.The Spotlight Cam is NOT that easy to install.In any event, everything "seems" to work but I'm not so sure about the motion detection. The live cam works, the lights and alarm works (when activated),  The mic to speak and listen both also seem to work.  But, when I jumped up and down in front of the cam, I never got a motion alert and the lights didn't go on as (as they should have based on how I set it up.  However, I did get a couple of random motion alerts after I finished installing the cam on the wall.  So, I'm not sure what is going on.Later learned, after speaking w/Ring CS again, that the lights only go on when it's dark (duh!!).  So, I still have to check to see if the motion detector and lights work when it's dark.  The only reason I can think of (and Ring CS didn't know any better) why the motion detector didn't go on when I jumped up and down in front of it, was because the motion detector is infra red and it was extremely hot out which may have impaired the ability of the infra red detector to "see me."Will have to check this again when it's darker and cooler out but I may not be able to do that b4 returning from vacation.  Oh well . . . "best best laid plans  . . . "

Review Title: Good for outdoor use, needs subscription to save video
Review Text: I originally had my spotlight camera indoors, and I was not a fan. The quality of the camera was good, but the spotlight was very annoying (depending on the amount of light in your house, it can be more than a tad overzealous). After speaking with Ring, I am now using a stick-up camera, and it is working much better indoors. I would recommend going that route instead if considering this for indoor use.A couple of other things to note are battery life and subscription. To put it bluntly, the battery life on the spotlight camera is not good. Ring has a solar panel option that offsets this, so I would recommend getting that instead of the standard battery model. With one battery, I couldn't get more than a few weeks out of a full charge (possibly related to the aforementioned issues with an overzealous spotlight). Additionally, you do need a subscription to save any video with these cameras. They only save video to the cloud, so to get the full use of your camera you need to pay $3/month for one device, or $10/month for multiple devices.I will also say that Ring's customer service is very good. They made sure I had the correct device for my particular situation, and have been very accommodating.

Review Title: The Installation for Battery Spotlight Cam Is Easy
Review Text: I purchased 2 spotlight battery cameras directly from Ring. I have had them  up a week. One battery  depleted in 2 days. The other is 50% after 5 days. Another camera on less active side has a better battery life. One battery is 50% after week and the other is still 100%.The company that installs contracted through Amazon does not install in my area and it took a long while to learn that and it delayed getting my cameras up far too long.  Since mine are not wired I finally found a neighbor to attach them to each side of my mobile.  I connected them to the internet with ease (I'm 82.) There are different settings but most of my notifications must be birds or the wind blowing bushes and trees. I do get s good range but in order to get my back porch, door and shed entrance I cant see my car in the carport. I can see anyone park on the street and i get almost al kml vehicles,  bicycles, golf carts and pedestrians going by as well as my neighbor across the street.I just changed internet speed from 50/50 to 75/75 today and there is noticeable improvement in download/upload speed to see live view. 100/100 would be even better.UPDATE Jul 23, 2019:  I live in a mobile and I am having difficulty getting a good signal and I have black screens at times or it takes a long time to bring up the screen.  My phone has plenty of memory etc and I optimize my phone several times a day.  I have been on the phone several times, and several times a day at times trying to solve the problem of my RSSI of 65, 70 etc.  Sunday, Jul 21st, I installed Ring Chime which is supposed to extend my WI Fi for the camera to work.  I connected both cameras to the Ring chime and it has not improved the RSSI except by a few numbers.  I have been told several times by customer service that the RSSI number has to be below 50.  The Chime itself is 34 and numbers around that.  With the assistance of customer service I moved the Chime to the few electric outlets I have and it really isn't improving my Ring RSSI numbers.  I disconnected one of the cameras from the Chime but the number of the other Ring Camera has not improved.  This is an old mobile home, built in 1971.  A single wide.  I have read possible the material of the construction, in my case, metal covering, could be cause for poor signal.  I do not have anyone at hand at my beck and call to help me get on a ladder and press the top button but as soon as I figure out how to do it (I climbed on chairs and stools and held on to the water heater cabinet on one side so I was able to press the button on one of them.  I'm 82 with bad back and knees and should not be doing this.  The ladder is too heavy for me and I fell off it once so I can't use it now.)  As soon as I can get someone to press that button on the one camera so I can change to my regular WI FI I will return the Chime.  I know this is a review of the camera but my point is the suggestion of adding the Chime did not help in my case.  The customer service also said I should move the camera and I would not be able to see my porch and shed access if I move it over.  It would be right in the open where if we have rains would rain on it.  Ring is a good product but all I am saying is for me it has been disappointing.  After I increased my internet speed the RSSI number was perfect for 12 hours and the picture immediately came on the mobile.  I am not sure I will keep Ring.  I have found that a skunk walks near my patio almost nightly. I get a lot of pics where nothing is shown to be causing it to record.  I am not sure it is worth it to record someone who stole plants and yard decorations 4 times recently but the person trying to get in my door at 1:30 a.m. could have been a one time thing.  The so called salesmen coming to my house at 7:30 pm and the same ones to my neighbors at 9:30 p.m. are what inspired me to get security cameras.  Oh, and the 3 different men who are "lost" and cannot find who they came in to see and knock on my door … they have no name, unit number (one finally said he had a unit number 365 but the numbers only go to 300) and no phone number for who they are to contact.  This happens so infrequently and looking thru so many videos (I live on a corner unit just yards from the street) I'm not sure this is worth it. There have been a few times the picture is black. Maybe a bird is blocking the lens but I don't know. I wish recorders filmed a bit longer sometimes.The helpline staff has been really been supportive with great follow up.So far nothing nefarious has recorded. I have seen a skunk go by 3 nights this week and it set the camera off.

Review Title: Limited to 30 sec. video clips, poor audio, easy to install
Review Text: I have been a user of a Ring door bell since 2015. And their products keep getting better. I recently sold my house and moved into an apartment. To make things simple, I purchased Ring's Alarm system bundle, with a battery powered doorbell and three battery spotlight cams. The doorbell and spotlight cams were easy to install and pair with the Ring Alarm System. All four cameras have a decently clear picture. However, two way audio is not clear either way.But the big disappointment is discovering that there is no way to adjust the recording length of the video clips. You had better hope that you capture useful video within the first 30 seconds of the motion activation. Otherwise you will have to wait at least another 60 seconds more before the cameras reset their motion activation. I wish I had discovered or read about this shortcoming before I purchase the battery version of these cameras. I would have chosen the wired versions of the spotlight cams instead.I assume Ring limited the video clips to 30 seconds to save on battery power. However, Ring should have let the user adjust the recording (and/or motion sensor activation) length or at least allow the video to continue for as long as there is motion detected. I would have rather have shorter battery power, with spare batteries to swap out, and capture useful video than have cameras that miss useful recordings. After all whats the point of the cameras if they do not capture the activity?
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019

Review Text: These Ring products are HIGHLY over-rated! The audio and video signals are not clear. The audio cuts in and out to the point where conversing with the person at your door is simply not possible. The video gets pixelated and is difficult to view. The camera itself is sub-standard. Anything within 10 feet is clear but beyond that it's just a blur. You would think with today's camera lens technology Ring could provide a more distant clear field of view. But it does not. Anyone or anything that causes the alarm to kick in - and is more than 10 feet away from the Doorbell may as well be wearing a disguise because you will surely not be able to discern who or what it is that set off the alarm. Then there's the latency between the time the Camera triggers an alarm and the time when you actually get to view the video. Review Title: WARNING: Motion Zone feature shown in this listing is misleading. App has changed.
Review Text: The camera itself is pretty good. Setup was easy, lights are powerful, picture quality is great. One general issue is that at night, when the spotlights turn on, the camera of course switches from night vision to normal and the footage looks pretty grainy as a result. But can't have perfection.If you are like me and looking for more advanced motion zone control than other battery cameras offer, and saw the image in this listing of a range setting in the app, be warned that the App is now different and that entire feature is misleading. You can no longer set Range on this unit.Now when you go to motion Zones in the app, you will get a still shot direct from your camera that has three zone segments laid over it similar to image in this listing above. You can turn each segment on and off, but there is no Range slider as pictured on this listing. On the following screen, you get a slider for Sensitivity, and this is what Ring support told me was the new "Range" slider. But I had already tried that and while it did reduce motion triggers from traffic on a road in front of the house, it also reduced sensitivity right in front of the camera itself. So it's clear this is a very crude solution. Since this was the major draw for my purchase, this is the reason for two stars instead of four. I don't appreciate making a decision to buy something from utterly misleading marketing material.Support are pretty good but couldn't help with this issue. They were easy to get hold of and listened to the problem. But it was clear that even my agent was unaware that this had changed as she was directing me to an interface that didn't exist. Even their internal script was outdated. She also offered to replace my Battery cam with a powered model for more advanced motion zones, but that was going to end up costing me as I am in New Zealand.

Review Text: I purchased the Ring security system about a year and a half ago and have since added multiple Ring cameras, including a video doorbell. Review Text: Ok i have purchased 2 of Ring Spotlight CAMS and can tell you they are great and work amazing. Battery life is also great!.However, to show you my honest review it is important to know how i started and where i ended up. There are some gotchas BUT there are solutions that work and worth looking in to. It all boils down to Frequency, Activity and Location.Lets startAs most users i started with Ring Pro Doorbell.Then i purchased a 2 pack of the Spotlight Cams (Cheaper than buying 1 wired and 1 battery cam - due to holiday savings)I set my Battery spotlight cam up for Frequent motion monitoring, Liveview enabled, and Light on for activity. This drains the battery the most. SO i used both batteries from the kit in the single camera and purchased 2 more batteries for the second camera. Lesson Learned. My Garage has more activity than a krispy kreme store (Well seems that way to me). So the battery would drain nearly 10% in a single day.  That means with 2 batteries i will get around 20-30 days of usage before i need to charge the batteries again. Didn't like that option so i purchased a wired cam, the wired cam was the clear winner in the garage.Now i have 2 battery spotlight cams with 2 batteries each and where do i put those?These were put outside so i could see the entry points to our house. Perfect! Activity is not as bad Literally a fraction if that. 2 batteries is an overkill for this situation but now i have a camera that drops 2-3% a day with the same settings. that means i can get about a month out of each battery (but there are two, so 2-3 months before charging)Reality,... WHO wants to have to pull out the batteries and charge them every 2-3 months?  Its not a big deal, but i am lazy.  So i was going to purchase 2 more batteries so i had 2 batteries ready for swap out while i charged the old ones. still seemed kinda lame as an option (again i am lazy) SO i purchased the Ring solar Panel (x2). THIS IS A MUST FOR BATTERY SPOTLIGHT CAMS IN MY OPINION.  Now they are recharged to 100% each day and never need my attention unless the battery goes bad.  IN about 2 hours of sunlight the camera replenishes roughly 12-16% of battery charge; based on my location in sunny Arizona. This  was a worthwhile investmentThis long review is just to tell you where i started and where i ended up at.NOW - The Spot light camera is perfect for all intents and purpose and works well, you won't be disappointed.But based on your activity, settings and location it hamper battery life. If you leave it on the default settings (Which honestly work fine) you can expect at least a 1-2 month life for each battery, maybe 3 months. If you are using dual batteries you may get twice that. BUT if you are going to be putting this camera outside i would go with 1 battery and solar panel, it is the best option.Camera siren will get attention, the light is bright, and the connectivity is not bad at all. most of mine are in the RSSI range of 32-49 which is perfectly fine. really 58 and down you are actually safe..lessons learned:Spot light battery cam Default settings one battery moderate activity (charge last 1-2 months)Wired cam has no issue with charge (because it is plugged into AC) But does have a few other options for Light brightness as well as motion activity zones.Solar Panels - Unbelievably the best combo for the Battery Cams.My Advice, pic up two, better to have the two pack and save some cash and set them up as needed. Great quality, reliable and work well. Just understand your need, application, and frequency to make sure you get what meets your needs. Which i didn't do, but in the end it all worked out and we couldn't be happier with our product.My setup right now consist ofRing ChimeRing Chime ProRing Doorbell Pro2 Spotlight Cams1 Wire Spotlight Cam2 Solar PanelsAll RSSI are in the range of 32-49 and work flawlessly. Ring app is also great to have and works as expected (Yes, you can download the app and use it without having to buy cams if you want to monitor what people are posting - which i would recommend)OVER ALL BUY IT, YOU WILL LIKE IT, WE DO.

Do not buy, I do not recommend, and I would definitely look elsewhere for your personal security and surveillance needs. I will say on a positive note, the only ring product I kept is the Ring Pro doorbell.

Review Text: Setup was simple and easy. WiFi connection is strong at mount point. We got it all up and running, and walk in front of the camera ... the light doesn't illuminate! We get the notifications of motion, but the light only comes on once in a while. It finally came on after 5 or 6 minutes, and then once it turns off, it doesn't come back on for another 5-10 minutes. Returning to Best Buy first thing in the morning tomorrow.EDIT: A Ring rep reached out and was gracious in finding out my issue and offering suggestions, and has agreed to send the wired version of the camera to see if that works better. I am extremely impressed with the customer service alone, so I will be updating this review just as soon as I get the new device, I don't know of any other company that would go this far to try to make things right. Bravo, Alexis from Ring!EDIT: I am absolutely floored with the amazing customer service Ring has provided me over the past few weeks. They sent me a new Doorbell Pro without even me asking (just because they noticed my motion settings were cranked down on my classic version), they sent me a wired version of the spotlight camera as I mentioned, and they even went as far as sending me a mount version of the spotlight camera when I couldn't get the wired connected due to my outside plugs being dead. My Ring support Rep Alexis was patient and understanding during my multi-week attempts to get everything sorted, and eventually I was able to get the wired one installed outside and it is working fantastic so far. I went ahead and updated my review to 3 stars- even though this specific product (spotlight camera battery) did not work for me, the absolutely above and beyond customer service warrants 3 stars just by itself. I am going to use the Spotlight Cam Wired for a week then post a new review on it, and I am sure it will be 4+ stars just based on the build quality and responsiveness I have noticed already. Its insane how much more sturdy and well made the Wired version feels, and since its not trying to conserve power all the time it lights up perfectly and detects motion like a champ! If you are thinking about buying a Ring Spotlight Cam battery, go ahead and get yourself the Wired or Mount version instead so you can get a better idea of the great functionality the power-connected versions offer. It makes sense that the battery ones are less responsive because they are trying to conserve power, but for something that you use for home security you will definitely want the power connected versions!!!I am a full blown Ring Supporter due to all the great customer service I have received and I can't wait to add more of the power connected versions of their cameras to my already fabulous Ring ecosystem! My Ring Alarm system has been flawless since day one, the Doorbell classic and Doorbell Pro are great devices, and the Spotlight Cam Wired and Mount are great too. Its really nice having all my systems hooked into one app too. Hoping someday they will get HomeKit integration, but I don't mind since it's all in one place in an app. Thanks Alexis from Ring! Review Title: This camera is awesome. I was looking for a solar option and ...
Review Text: This camera is awesome.  I was looking for a solar option and this is it.  With the optional solar panel,  I have never seen the battery get below 80% in the night. I highly recommend this.  My only complaint is when the motion triggers as the light changes, i.e. you see the footage kind of flash with the change of sunlight during the day.  I won't dock this a star, as other manufacturers have the same problems.  I have ip cameras that I am phasing out for ring, they all do this.  This was simple and easy to install.  I have their floodlight and doorbell pro cameras as well.I've seen a lot of complaints about connectivity.  People, please make sure you have a decent router.  The cheap 40-50 dollar routers of old do not cut it anymore.  You need a router that can handle up to 20 devices simultaneously, at a minimum.  You may need additional access points as well.  Take your phone where you are installing your cameras and compare connectivity.  If you have your router stuck in a cabinet, take it out.  That will affect your coverage as well.  Just my 2 cents.  I hope this helps.Update:  6/15/2018I have two of these cameras paired with the solar panel.  I never have to worry about the batteries.  I am very impressed with these spotlight cameras.  If you are on the fence, don't be.  They are well worth the money.  Get setup on the protect plan and you never have to worry about them again.

Review Title: Not a good outdoors camera due to sensitivity.
Review Text: Video quality, night vision, usability are all great. Where this product suffers is the reduced functionality. Poor motion sensing has the camera constantly picking up every change. The motion zone setup in the app is confusing as well, as the its displayed looking at you, so to adjust the left zone, its actually the right on how its displayed in the app. I've messed around for countless hours on the setting for my camera on the front porch, but constantly receive false alerts for wind, rain and small insects at all hours of the day and night. This causes me to ignore most alerts or silence it altogether, taking what I enjoyed of a proactive security approach, to a more reactive setting.When put inside, these are awesome, but from how they are designed (batteries and solar panels) to be outside, they are of poor design due to how the sensitivity is relatively locked.I'd suggest the wired versions as the can be programmed better and fine tuned with motion setting and sensitivity for places of higher traffic and element exposure. Leave the battery ones for more enclosed areas, like a mudroom or garage/workshop.

Review Text: Already having a robust camera system monitoring my house, I decided to get the ring to fill the voids where my previous cameras are not. Review Title: convenient, easy install for great enhanced security
Review Text: We've been using the Ring Spotlight Battery to monitor our front yard in combination with the Ring Doorbell and Ring Spotlight Wired for our backyard. The Ring Spotlight Battery was the easiest to setup, since no wires are needed. It's much lighter than the Ring Spotlight Wired so we have ours actually strapped to a tree in the front yard rather than screwed into the house. Video quality is excellent. Only issues have been that the battery powered Ring Spotlight Cam only allow setting motion sensitivity and zones, so it's a bit of trial and error. We do get many more false positives, but the only alerts I send to my phone are for the doorbell and backyard. The front (where this is) I'll review if there's anything suspicious, so this works ok. It does records about 5-10 videos per day, and I'd say first battery lasted about 4 months before requiring recharge including high usage sessions (x3-4) when I was trying various parts around our yard for setup. Ring Spotlight Wired has many less false positives since you can draw out exactly what you want to monitor, rather than have general zones like the Ring Doorbell (1st gen) and Ring Spotlight Wireless. It did require a lot of trial and error both adjusting location and adjusting motion sensitivity settings, so before screwing it in especially if you have several trees with long branches like we do, I'd recommend avoiding screwing it in until you're absolutely sure after a few weeks you have a good location.We considered Nest cam, Blink XT, and Arlo.  With Nest, we didn't actually want to record everything 24/7, especially if we had 3-4 cameras we were concerned about killing our bandwidth. With Arlo, we didn't want to have a separate base station when we have great mesh wifi to work off of, and I didn't like the lithium batteries either if I had reasonable outlets nearby or good rechargables. Blink seemed to have less features and again required a separate base station.

Review Text: I purchased two of these cameras from Home Depot but Ring asked me to leave a review on Amazon. These cameras are extremely easy to activate and install. All activation and setup are done from the Ring App which makes the process pretty simple. I did have to let the batteries charge for about eight hours before installing the cameras, which was a bit of a bummer because I wanted to set them up as soon as I opened the box. These cameras have great picture quality and I've had no issues receiving alerts on my iPhone.  The two-way talk feature also works nicely, I'm able to quickly log on via the app and talk with whoever is at my door.
