Review Title: With *very* reliable internet (which I bet you don't have), it's not worth it.
Review Text: I really want to like this unit. I bought two of them, and a ring doorbell even!  But I will say that it took me a while to get both the front and back working at all.  Once I was able to get video on my android device for front and back, I notice that it records blank video probably 1 our of every 10 times or more.  Okay, it doesn't record locally, it has to record to the internet (at $30 a year per camera).  And even though my upload and download speed is normally 60Mbs down/10Mbs up, it appears that upload is not reliable.  This makes it's all but worthless as an actual security camera.Also, the idea that some one walks up to your door, you get notified on you phone, you answer and talk to them at the door via you phone is a cute idea.  but it takes 5-10 seconds or longer for the initial notification them several more seconds to get video.  After 10-15 seconds, people at the door are not there any more.  It records them sitting there - actually the first few seconds are often very choppy, maybe a few frames, after that it gets better.So I'll place the blame squarely on the "internet".  You are not guarenteed latency (quick turnaround).  Even with ping times of 10ms and up/down of 50/5 very reliably, all it takes is some hiccup.I've worked with several routers.  Wifi connection is excellent (it's sitting right next to my router as I type).Without a local means of capturing video reliable and then uploading it, this is not a very useful device.  For $200 per camera + $30 / camera (or $10 a month of unlimited camera), it sounds great.  But keep your receipts and be prepared to ask for more bw from your internet provider.  If that even helps (it doesn't for me).Now, after two weeks, one camera will not stream no matter what we do with it.  Motion detection works fine, I can remotely turn on the flood light (thought that takes a min of 5 seconds - apparently the signal has to go to from my phone to ring then back to the unit).  I suspect I have a bad unit.In any case, I really have to say you are at the mercy of the internet with this device.  I get that Ring wants a month payment (that's the modern world) and I'd rather save video locally (and slowly back up to google drive or whatever) which would make it less likely I'd pay them monthly for storage.I've waded through all the help I can find.All in all this current product is unreliable.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2018

Review Title: Not as good as other Ring cams

Review Title: In an hour I was good to go
Review Text: Easy to setup and install. The Ring company includes all the necessary tools (minus the power drill) to mount the device and get you up and running within an hour. You just have to decide beforehand where to mount the device. The instructions do recommend you charge the battery for a longer period but if you need immediate surveillance the battery is low but it is good to go. I found it easier to sync the device with your WiFi before you actually climb up a ladder and mount the device on the wall. This will save you a trip climbing back up the ladder and push the sync button on the top of the device if needed.If you have multiple Ring devices like myself, then think of name of the location before mounting the devices. The Ring app comes with the default locations for where you are going to mount the device i.e. front and backyard but you can customize the name of the locations for example pool area, basketball court, North Shore, DMZ etc.Once the device is connected on your WiFi and mounted then you are good to go. There is a warranty that if your device is stolen by the suspect Ring will replace it. Ring does offer a $3/ month service fee to have your footage available on their cloud subscription. That’s your call, everybody has their own priorities, that’s all I will say about that. It was a yes for me.You do not need to be tech savvy or be Mr. Home improvement. You just need about an hour of time, where you are going mount the device and name the device. My take away point, I like the fact that I don’t have to wire a power cable to the device, it has a rechargeable. I recommend shortening the perimeter of your motion zone, this will extend your battery life in-between charges. Would I recommend the devices, 100%! I actually like to order more, I just have to plan on where to mount the devices.

Review Title: Initially pleased, then annoyed by poorly thought out design and flaws
Review Text: I purchased a total of 3 spotlight cameras and 1 doorbell camera to cover the outside of my entire house. The system was relatively inexpensive (under $700) and installed easily. With no wires to run I was able to mount all 4 cameras in under 2 hours. I mounted the spotlight cameras to my house siding with construction screws and the doorbell to the door frame. The Ring app for Android was easy to use and I quickly was able to connect to and monitor the cameras from my phone. Video clarity is pretty impressive in daylight and acceptable at night. The ability to share videos with your neighbors and directly with the police are also positives. Initially I was very happy and would have given the product a 5 star rating, but as time went on I became increasingly annoyed with the product. When mounted at the recommended height, the spotlight cameras cannot be aimed down enough due to the bulky body and poorly thought out bracket. Combined with the fisheye-style lens, this causes the motion sensors to pick up every car, person, animal passing by and even flag blowing in the wind across the street. Reducing the motion sensitivity to reduce these false alarms enough allows a person to almost be able to touch my house before the cameras catch them. I am constantly getting motion alerts on my phone and it is at the point where I all but completely ignore them. Battery life is also poor. The cameras need to be recharged every couple weeks and charging a single battery takes a good 6-8 hours when it is depleted. I haver also yet been able to figure out how to have the ring doorbell ring my actual digital doorbell. If my phone is on silent, I miss when someone is at the door. I plan to modify the provided camera mounting brackets to attempt to solve some of these issues but if I were to do it again, I would have purchased a high end surveilance system.

Review Title: Not as good as Ring’s Doorbell or Floodlight Cameras
Review Text: I have the Ring doorbell and the Ring Floodlight Camera as well.  Unfortunately. This Spotlight Camera is my least favorite of the three.  My main complaint is that the Doorbell and Floodlight versions both give you the ability to “draw” motion zones so that you can exclude high-traffic areas from generating alerts. On the other cameras, it significantly reduces false alarms when set to “People Only.”  In fact, I had to turn the Motion Alerts off on this Spotlight Cam because it was sending alerts every time a tree would move in a gentle breeze.  In short, the Ring Spotlight Cam is almost as expensive as Ring’s other products, but only half as useful.

Review Text: ***UPDATE***Shortly after this post, I was contacted by Alexis, a Neighbor Advocate at Ring. She listened to my problem, sympathized, and diagnosed the situation. Thank you Alexis and thank you Ring!Our mailbox was stolen right off the front wall near the sidewalk it was mounted to. So we got the Ring Spotlight Cam to monitor our new mailbox. So far, after 3 months of ownership, I have never seen the mailman put mail in our mailbox. The sensor picks up EVERY single car driving on our street, but it will not pick up someone walking right in front of our house, or UPS/FedEx putting packages in our yard, or anyone walking on our property, or me and my wife pulling out of or onto our driveway in our cars. It just blows my mind that it can pick up a car driving on the other side of the street, but someone walking up to our front door passing right underneath it will go undetected. Review Title: Great, until you want to review past videos
Review Text: The Ring spotlight is a great product and I really want to like it. I don't have any issues with battery or the product itself. I just don't like being locked in with a subscription model. I like the concept of Ring spotlight + battery, but I've paired it with the Wyze Cam, which has an SD card for video, and also includes Cloud recording without extra charges (but needs 5v power). That makes it a better long term solution compared to the Ring. So now I use the Ring for the spotlight and being able to "answer" live real-time alerts, while using Wyze Cam to view stored recordings. Review Title: Ring is the BEST investment we made in 2018!  And here's why....
Review Text: There tends to be a lot of research when looking for the right "security/monitoring" solution for our homes.  My brother was always a DIY kind of guy, and I let him run with it.  He set up a system at his place and mine as well.  My Ring introduction started from a Prime Day deal. I can't stress this enough.  Everything you need is in the box:  clear instructions, pictures, access to high-quality videos, drill bits, screw driver, etc.  So the hardware part is done perfectly.  Even more important is the 'software' part - namely the Ring app.  The way it walks you through the addition of devices, and the way it let's you set-up your motion zones and all other settings just shows this was tested so well.  I remain completely impressed with the product, enjoy the security/peace-of-mind it gives me, and how it also connects me to my Ring neighborhood.  The cost (monthly/yearly) IF you want to maintain access to your videos a bit longer is very affordable.  Well done Ring!  I'm currently using 5 Ring devices across 2 homes and couldn't be happier.

Review Text: I bought this simply to keep an eye on my porch deliveries and see who's at the door before I bother opening it. The battery-powered spotlight seemed like a good idea since I didn't want the hassle of running new electrical wire, drilling through my brick, or having exposed cords. I wish I had done more research on security cameras before buying, this one has been nothing but aggravation and doesn't even effectively do what I needed.My biggest problem is placement: when I install the device for optimal motion detection, the camera isn't positioned to capture the video I want. With the camera positioned for the view I need, it's only triggered when the motion happens right under its nose (and not even consistently then). We tried about a dozen mounting areas—high, low, middle, and every kind of angle—and in no case did we get functional motion detection and a decent video view. And because the motion doesn't get detected properly, the video doesn't record anything useful: sometimes I get a notification and see just a glimpse of someone walking away, or an empty porch where I later find a “missed delivery” paper. I have adjusted all the settings every which way and nothing makes this thing work right.I bought an extra battery and they're lasting pretty long since I have so few motion events that cause recording. The bottom part that flips open to change the batteries seems super flimsy, and even brand new it's been finicky to snap completely shut (you will get an error on the app when it's not snapped tight). The battery compartment releases with a press of a button, so I guess a criminal could (easily in my case) sneak up, pop them out, and continue with their mayhem undetected. I didn’t sign up for the Ring cloud service, because I rarely have motion-triggered video that shows me anything of consequence.Other notes: I didn't have issues connecting. When we were testing locations, a few of the farthest away from the router showed “poor connection” on the app Device Health tab, but the camera was still working fine even then. I did have intermittent problems launching the Live View from my iPad, although at those same times the same app on my iPhone connected to Live View fine. The spotlight is extremely bright and the siren loud enough, but the poor motion detection makes those functions pretty useless.Like they show on the commercial, the Ring spotlight and floodlight are probably designed for corner-of-the-house-mount-looking-out-over-the-long-driveway-or-yard kind of situation. My porch problem can't be solved by either of those products or the doorbell, so maybe my house configuration is a really unique situation. And when the motion doesn't work right, then the camera is useless except for Live View. Buy from someplace where you will have an easy return!
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2018

Review Text: I bought a Ring doorbell and two battery stick-up cams. The doorbell works fine; the stick-up cams are useless. Review Text: After having attempted home break-ins in our neighborhood, my wife and I discussed mounting an eternal camera to monitor our front yard initially.  Looking at the options available, we chose the Ring Spotlight Camera - Battery because we could install a solar charger with it.  The first camera was installed in about 20 minutes, after the battery was charged and work great for the first 12 hours.  Living in Alaska, the weather was cool and rainy and after 14 hours the software stated that the battery door was open, and that it should be checked out as soon as possible.  When checking the equipment, I saw that the battery door seal was compromised on one side and it may be allowing humidity and moisture in the camera.  The camera stopped working that evening.  Before going to bed that night, I sent a request to RIng online about the issue so I could address it the next day.  I talked to Ring Support the following day who were extremely responsive and helpful.  They asked if I could send pictures of what I was seeing and as soon as they saw how the seal was coming apart confirmed my need to replace the camera.  I had purchased the camera at a store in our town and had to explain why I was returning for exchange and that it was not customer error.  As Ring Support had given me a detailed email recommending a plan of action, the store was very helpful in exchanging the camera, and they were not going to have an issue getting their equipment exchanged as they had a detailed email from Ring to facilitate their return.  Ring Support was extremely helpful.Regarding the camera and solar panel.... they work outstanding.  The software is very user friendly and was easy to integrate to the WiFi.  I am currently about to install a Ring Doorbell next and am sold on Ring’s overall package of security equipment.

Review Title: Had to have a factory reset after three days, stopped working completely after five.
Review Text: Bought this camera to go above my garage as I already have a Ring Doorbell Pro and a stick camera in my living room. Set up on this camera was not as easy as the Ring WiFi was so very hard to try and get to connect. After three days, the battery was saying that it was dead. When I changed the battery, the system would not reboot, it would not recognize that there was a new fully charged battery, and it did not work. I deleted it from my devices list in the app and tried to restart the set up. At this point, I had to spend 40 minutes on the phone with a tech services person (she was amazing by the way and very patient and helpful). After speaking with her and trying over and over again to get the camera to set up and once it finally did, I took it out and mounted the camera above the garage again. This morning (day 5) the camera is no longer working at all. It last picked something up at 7:43AM. The camera did take static video all night long and just stopped working after it recorded a motion incident at 7:43AM - though it did not pick up the movement at the garage when my husband and I were leaving this morning at 7:10AM. When I got home this afternoon, I took the camera back down and followed the same steps as I did with the tech over the phone two days ago. The camera will not turn on at all. No flashing lights, no anything. The inside battery light will still glow red indicating that the battery is in and is charged, but otherwise there are no signs of life.I like having the security of knowing that I can see what is happening on my property at any given time, and because I already have a Ring Doorbell Pro and stick cam as stated above, I have chosen to order a new camera and send the other back. I hope that I do not have these same issues when the new one gets here, but if I do, I will be sure to update.I would like to mention that I have done my internet connection testing and my internet connectivity was reading at RSSI -58 which is within the range that the camera should be working well in. I have a WiFi extender that is close to the garage and the doorbell. I have tried as many different things as possible to connect and keep a good signal, so I know that connectivity is not the issue.

Review Text: Ring makes a great product....recommend them.HOWEVER, if you're planning on buying an additional battery for spotlight cams that have 2 slots, in order to extend the time between recharges, know before you buy, that the electronic designers decided to make it so the unit exhausts ONE battery completely, then switchs to the other battery.What this causes is a CONSTANT battery low warning on your phone app when the first one used is at 15% which is intolerable.Instead, they should have connected the batteries in parallel so they both get used at the same time which would double the time between recharges, which is why I bought the extra battery in the first place.Save your money or buy a solar charger so you NEVER have to recharge a difficult to access camera. Review Title: Ring spotlight cam security flaw- FIXED
Review Text: UPDATE: Initially, I gave the the Ring spotlight camera only TWO STARS because of the following situation:"The Ring Spotlight Cam was fine, working continuously for  about 5 months without any major issues. When the power interruption was over, my secondary wifi-based security system was immediately able to recover connectivity, but the Ring spotlight cams remained offline.  According to Ring tech support there is no way to get these cameras back online remotely.  The homeowner must come home to stand next to each camera and press a reset button! Forget Ring if you expect it to protect your property while you're on vacation. Fortunately I chose Simplisafe as my secondary backup security system, and when they come out with an outdoor cam I will buy it to replace these Ring spotlight cams. I'm glad I discovered this flaw in Ring before I invested in any more of their products."After a couple of days of offline Ring cameras, I decided to contact one of the Customer Satisfaction Specialists from the Amazon reviews of Ring cameras. She was highly responsive to the problem, and within half a day, my Spotlight cameras came back online. without me having to get back home to press the reset buttons. Very impressive Customer Service! Review Text: When the camera works, it works well.  It does what it says.  Set up is easy.  But due to a pretty important design flaw, it can be frustrating. If you’re not careful when positioning your camera in the mount, you can cause the camera to slip back into pairing mode.  The effect of this is to silently disconnect your camera from the network. Review Text: I have had two of these battery cameras for 10 months.  Bought them because of the battery option, and I really like the wired Ring flood light.  Their performance, however, is quite different from the flood light.PROS:1. Waterproof: one camera is out under the Florida sun and pouring rain, and it's still working2. As so many others have complained about the lag in the recording, this alone makes the camera quite useless.5. Enable/disable live view option is there to save battery, but it is a pain to enable because it doesn't take effect immediately.  Have to wait for a next motion event to occur and that could be a long wait.  When I want to view it live, I want to see it immediately, not six hours later.6. Motion zone and notification settings just don't work the way you want them to work.  They seem to be useless.7. Video quality is not as sharp as the wired flood light.8. Mounting plate does not allow the camera to tilt downward to view the foot of the wall where the camera is mounted.  For example, you can't quite see who's at the door if the camera is mounted above the door.9. One camera is connected to a wifi extender, and it records a black image more than 50% of the time.  Signal is strong enough so I don't know what the problem is.  It seems the black image occurs when other ring cameras are also recording.CONCLUSION: The camera does not give a worthwhile performance, not for $200.  I also got the Ring door bell at the same time I got these cameras, but I am going to throw it in the trash shortly after struggling with it; it's too late to return it, but it's another story.UPDATE 5/2019: One of my two Spotlight Battery cameras is dead after about 18 months in operations. Review Title: Ring does it again with the Ring Spotlight Cam - battery powered
Review Text: Ring has hit a home run with this Spotlight Cam unit. Installation was a piece of cake and the setup only takes a few minutes through the ring app.  The clarity of this Spotlight Cam is amazing..  Day Time/ Night Time, both have a great visual that will allow you to keep an eye on what is going on around the camera.  You can set the Spotlight Cam to have the LED lights come on with Motion or you can turn those off and only use those when you manually turn them on.  The Alarm is a great feature!!  If you see unwanted activity, you can actually set off an alarm that will give a high pitch alarm sound that comes from the Spotlight Cam and the bottom "globe light" will flash red.  Love this feature!  And as most of the Ring products, you can talk through your Ring App and your voice will come out on the Cam.  Overall, if you want a great reliable security camera that is easy to use, easy to setup, and does what it is supposed to and more, then look no further.  The Ring Spotlight Cam is what you want.. Love mine and will be buying more for my house.

Review Title: Battery version stops recording too soon
Review Text: This review is for the Battery version of the Spotlight Cam, connected to a Ring solar panel.  I also have the wired Doorbell Pro and battery Doorbell.This product has good picture and generally does a good job.  But it has a critical flaw: it almost always stops recording 30 seconds after it detects motion, even if the motion is continuing, and it will not restart recording motion for a period of time.  This is likely to preserve battery, but since I use the solar panel (which keeps the battery nearly full all of the time) this is not a concern for me.This flaw has consequences.  For example, recently a suspicious car pulled into my off-the-beaten-path driveway, where the camera is.  The Ring video shows the car pulling in, but as the person is about to exit the car, the video cuts off.  There is no more video.  There is no video of the car leaving.Assuming this is a software issue, Ring should reconsider how it prioritizes battery life vs complete video, especially for users who have a solar panel.  Or at least give users the option to prioritize longer recording over longer battery life.

Review Text: This really feels like a Beta testing product it is very expensive and has so many bugs and problems.  Expect to devote hours and hours trying to optimize every aspect of its use. You will have to buy and extra battery and a Solar panel unless you want to climb a ladder 2 twice a week. You will definitely need to buy a wifi extender - they will try to sell you their chime wifi extender product (dont buy it- it's junk) They're are many better extenders. Expect to be calling, chatting and emailing Ring many many times for many many hours. I spent just under 700 at ring plus another 140 for two wifi extenders plus 100 dollar a year service plan and i'm not sure I can justify any of it.The cameras rarely catch movement in time the video despite having excellent wifi signal, the video is blocking or choppy such that I would ever be able to use it to identify a suspect, beyond an object approached my house then teleported closer then teleported away from my house. Nightvision rarely works if at all. Live view takes so long to open up the person is long gone ( I spent hour trying to activate live view over and over before giving up last night). I would say at least I have a insanely expensive motion activated led light security light but that doesn't even work except 1 out of 50-60 times.  I honestly think if I bought a 30 dollar cheapy SD card camera it would function as good if not better and I would have 650+ dollars to buy a guard dog.I fully expect RING to take this product off the market at some point in 2018 they know it is a lemon but they have warehouses of product they need to empty; my guess is I will get a coupon for the next product and be shelling out another 700 for the non-BETA version of this camera sometime around winter 2018

Review Title: Issue out the box, avoid battery versions of ring at all costs
Review Text: Got the devices in yesterday, set the batteries to charge and today went to set them up. Both of my new battery cams constantly warn that the battery bay is open. My wired cameras and doorbell work great most of the time, but these battery devices are just bad. Didn't read about them first because my other items are great, but turns out the battery warning has been an issue for 3 years and they refuse to acknowledge it's a problem or fix it. I also hear the battery lasts only a few weeks, which is really bad. Was going to get solar panels later, but seems it's just going to be better to return them. Not sure how they went from solid wired products to barely usable battery ones.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2021

Review Title: Not What it Used to Be :/
Review Text: Boy, this product and company has gone downhill! Support is overseas, so good luck there. My rep couldn’t understand that I wanted to reuse my name/number but every thing else was new.The mounting piece is poorly designed in that it doesn’t allow for the heavy device to sit in it securely while one adjusts for optimal position without seeming like it will fall out. Also, some indication of which is top vs. the bottom of the mount would be nice as I installed one upside down:(It did not alert me to anything, especially a low battery, like the app used to do back in the early days.If mounting near a door, it should be low not high up as pics and videos show for two reasons. One, ability to change the battery that lasts a stupidly short time. Second, to capture the height of say, below the waste of the average visitor, since panning down with the device risks it popping out of the base. Capturing those packages being delivered to a porch is not an option with this! Best for mounting to capture at a distance.In the end, two of these purchased were a very expensive mistake! Going back to my crappy Blink devices!
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2022

Review Text: I have two of the spotlight battery cameras and I love them.  I will be purchasing a 3rd in the near future.  The setup was extremely easy and they installed in less than 5 minutes. The video quality is exceptional, I can clearly see the target area.  My only issue is there is a slight delay at times regarding the alert, but that it isn't significant is not always an issue.  The battery lasts a LONG time.  Mind, I changed my settings so they are "snoozing" when I am outside with my dogs or doing other things in the yard.  I did notice that the multiple alarms would drain the battery quickly, but using the snooze function works for me.I wasn't sure what the night vision would look like but I am pleasantly surprised.  I see a clear video at night and the spotlight, while not illuminating a big part of my yard, does the job.  I am very happy with these and am thankful they are battery operated so I did not have to worry about wiring.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2021

Review Text: I cannot begin to describe to you the utter joy and relief my wife and I feel now that we own this and have it installed. We live in a rural area and it's nice to know that whether I'm home or not, my home is better protected. Clear picture, easy setup. Batteries last decently (I would suggest getting back ups if you watch them a lot or if you live in a busy area). Batteries take about 5-6 hours to charge but once they're charged, they last for about two weeks with us (my wife watches it ALL THE TIME so our batteries drain exponentially fast). Do still get some false alarms from time to time (wind blowing the trees causing a lot of motion/animals in the neighborhood set it off, etc.)While these are awesome and weather resistant, weather can and will still affect it (to some degree). Rain can sometimes be an issue (water droplets on the screen which will need to be wiped/cleaned off) and at night, we had an issue sometimes with our camera fogging over. Simple fix: Go get de-fogger for glasses (like reading glasses). Follow the instructions and you shouldn't have an issue with fog on the camera anymore. We did that and haven't had an issue since.Super fast shipping and a pretty decent price for the peace of mind that we now have adding this to our camera collection. Would definitely recommend and am getting more in the near future!
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on May 8, 2020

Review Title: Worse cam comparing to the Bell & Stick Up
Review Text: I own 3 different types of Ring cams (bell, outdoor stick up 2nd gen, & spotlight). This Spotlight cam is the worst.During the daytime, the sensor only picks up motion at ~20 ft (in front of it) instead of the claimed 30 ft. The detection distance is significantly shorter at night.The video was fine in a dry day. But we had a some rain last night, and the camera became extremely foggy. Whereas my stick up cam still gets crystal clear images.I’ll keep it. But this device needs some tune up.

Review Title: RING NEW FEATURE APP UPDATE RENDERS DETECTION USELESS
Review Text: I would highly NOT RECOMMEND RING CAMERAS!After several years of working a Ring home alarm and cameras and dealing with antiquated functions and performance, Ring made a bad system even worst with the latest update.The latest "smart alert" settings render human detection notification worthless, nada, non-functioning.while it will detect and alert a solo or a group of people walking by it will not alert you or a person's presence if that individual arrived in a vehicle. If delivery personnel parks in front of your house and proceeds to exit the vehicle and drops off the package at your front door RING camera will read it as a "Motion", not a "Person". this brings me to my dilemma of which I want to be notified if a person enters my yard.After contacting Ring SEVERAL times with my issue and complaints, I was finally told that there is nothing any customer rep and can do other than resetting the camera and function settings or keep making adjustments. Review Title: Ring let us down too many times
Review Text: If you need an easy method to setup a security camera to view your property in real time with low expectations Ring outdoor cameras will work for the most part.  I made a big investment and bought 3 cameras and the Protection Plus plan (over $500) which has let me down on multiple occasions.1.  The Ring camera motion did not capture 2 car break-ins as the Motion Zone shown is actually smaller than what is shown in the camera, so the thieves never triggered the motion recording near our car despite the motion line having both cars in the shot.  Passing cars from the street triggered motion recordings which created gaps between recordings to preserve batteries before resuming the recording (I have the solar panels installed now to reduce time outs).2.  The Ring Camera captured a still image of our 17-year-old American Home Shield Installed Heat Pump igniting something in mid-air after the defrost cycle started next to my daughter's window.  I was glad that I had a Ring camera setup in the backyard with the option to see the footage on the Ring App until Ring Representatives said the company automatically deletes still images after 7 days despite saying you have 30 days of coverage using the pro plan and Ring will not try to recover the images if needed for legal purposes.  Luckily, I was able to look back and screen capture my phone since before the footage was deleted (the Ring website won't show the same footage as it appears on the phone).  I needed to show independent footage from the Ring app because American Home Shield will try claim that that I doctored/photoshopped a downloaded image.  American Home Shield wants a technician to get our 7-year-old unit functioning again so they can check the box that the unit works to get out of paying for a replacement.  Since Ring's tech support will not help in recovering the footage they deleted, I cannot count on Ring to support us moving forward and will need to replace our units.

Review Title: Great sense of security, easy to use
Review Text: I've had this camera (with the solar panel) for almost a year now and it's still going strong. I love that I can monitor my home from inside or 1500 miles away. We had a stalker situation last year and were able to show the police proof of all we'd be telling them, leading to them confronting the stalker and threatening indictment if he didn't stop (which he did).I still haven't been able to effectively set the motion boundary so that it picks up everything I want it to while leaving out what I don't. I've had to just leave it covering a pretty broad area. Even still, sometimes it will miss and only catch motion after the fact. I'm not sure why. But it gets it about 90% of the time, which has been very helpful.I want to install a second but the price is a little steep for me right now. Otherwise, it's a great value for all that you get. I definitely recommend the solar panel, though, especially if you live in an area that gets sun 90% of the year like we do in the desert southwest. Just mount it on top of your roof, face it upwards and you're good to go, even on cloudy, stormy days. Mounting both the camera and panel was pretty simple and quick to do with an electric screwdriver.

Review Text: Presently I have four Ring Cams for security outside of the home. I recently purchased a battery cam with a solar panel since I did not want to drill a large hole in the outside wall of my house  to install the Ring mount hardwire cam. So I ordered the Ring Spotlight battery HD Cam. I also ordered the Ring Solar Panel and Ring wall mount that holds the Cam & Solar Panel.The wire from the Solar Panel is 13 ft long. Since I am using the wall mount that hold both the Solar Panel and the Cam there was no way of hiding the excessively long bundle of wire. I spoke to one of the Ring Techs, and he said it was permissible to cut and splice the wire. I knew from the flexible wire that it was not a solid copper wire but would be several thin strands. I inquired if the insulated wire had one  or  two  bundles, the tech said it was just one. Once I cut the wire, I discovered he was wrong. there were two bundles, one red and the other blue. As you can see from my photo how I splice the two ends. The wire bundles are very small and the several strands within very thin, so you must be very careful in striping the insulation from the strands. I cut a wire connector in half, inserted the two ends of the wire and crimped the connected with a crimping tool. I wrapped each ends with electrical tape.I drilled two 1/4 inch holes in the Ring wall mount to hide the wires. (however, 3/16 " hole would be sufficient) If you decide to do this, be sure to insert the wires through the holes of the Ring mount before you splice the  two ends together.As you can see from my Cam and Solar Panel mounted on the wall how finished it appears without the long bundle of excessive wire hanging behind the Solar Panel.The wire behind the Solar Panel is fixed and not detachable as the one that attaches to the back of the Camera. If anyone of you feel this is what you want to do, then after cutting the wire attached to the Solar Panel, you may want to practice stripping the insulation on the excessive wire left over before you attempt to strip the insulation from the Solar Panel wire and the one that will attach to the Cam.I hope you find this helpful.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2022
